Tight Stability, Convergence, and Robustness Bounds for Predictive Coding Networks

Ankur Mali
University of South Florida
Tampa, FL 33620, USA
{ankurarjunmali}@usf.edu
&Tommaso Salvatori
VERSES AI Research Lab
Los Angeles, California, USA
{tommaso.salvatori}@verses.ai
\ANDAlexander G. Ororbia
Rochester Institute of Technology
1 Lomb Drive, Rochester NY
ago@cs.rit.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Ankur Mali1, Tommaso Salvatori2,3, Alexander G. Ororbia4
1 University of South Florida Tampa, FL 33620, USA
2 VERSES AI Research Lab, Los Angeles, USA
3 Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria
4 Rochester Institute of Technology 1 Lomb Drive, Rochester NY
{ankurarjunmali}@usf.edu, Â  {tommaso.salvatori}@verses.ai, Â  ago@cs.rit.edu
Abstract

Energy-based learning algorithms, such as predictive coding (PC), have garnered significant attention in the machine learning community due to their theoretical properties, such as local operations and biologically plausible mechanisms for error correction. In this work, we rigorously analyze the stability, robustness, and convergence of PC through the lens of dynamical systems theory. We show that, first, PC is Lyapunov stable under mild assumptions on its loss and residual energy functions, which implies intrinsic robustness to small random perturbations due to its well-defined energy-minimizing dynamics. Second, we formally establish that the PC updates approximate quasi-Newton methods by incorporating higher-order curvature information, which makes them more stable and able to converge with fewer iterations compared to models trained via backpropagation (BP). Furthermore, using this dynamical framework, we provide new theoretical bounds on the similarity between PC and other algorithms, i.e., BP and target propagation (TP), by precisely characterizing the role of higher-order derivatives. These bounds, derived through detailed analysis of the Hessian structures, show that PC is significantly closer to quasi-Newton updates than TP, providing a deeper understanding of the stability and efficiency of PC compared to conventional learning methods.

1 Introduction

The successes of artificial intelligence (AI) over the past decade have been primarily driven by deep learning, which has become a cornerstone in modern machine learning. Despite these remarkable achievements, there has been a resurgence of interest in exploring alternative paradigms for training neural networks [1, 2]. This renewed interest stems from the inherent limitations of standard backpropagation-based training (BP) [3], such as high computational overhead, energy inefficiency, and biological implausibility [4, 5]. As a result, there has been a revival of energy-based learning methods that were initially popularized in the 1980s, such as Hopfield networks [6], equilibrium propagation [7], contrastive Hebbian learning [8], and predictive coding [9]. These models, which minimize a general energy functional [5], employ local update rules that are well-suited for both spiking neural networks [10, 11] and neuromorphic hardware implementations [12].

Among these approaches, predictive coding (PC) stands out due to its intriguing theoretical properties and practical performance. Originally developed to model hierarchical information processing in the neocortex [13, 14], PC has shown remarkable performance in a wide range of machine learning tasks, such as image classification and generation [15, 16], continual learning [17], associative memory formation [18, 19], and reinforcement learning [20]. In addition to its practical applications, recent work has focused on analyzing PC from a theoretical standpoint, examining its stability and robustness properties [21, 22]. Prior investigations have drawn parallels between PC and other learning frameworks, such as BP and target propagation, but have not provided rigorous and tight bounds on the stability and robustness of PCâ€™s updates [23, 24]. Existing bounds are often based on first-order approximations [25], overlooking the impact of higher-order derivatives, which are crucial for understanding stability in non-linear systems.

A rigorous theoretical study of stability is essential for ensuring convergence to fixed points and robustness under various perturbations, which is crucial for applications such as noisy inputs or uncertain synaptic parameters. Stability has been shown to enhance the performance of neural networks in complex scenarios, e.g., sequence length generalization [26], symbolic rule extraction [27, 28], and stable prediction dynamics [29, 30, 31]. In biologically-motivated learning, where models are deployed on hardware platforms susceptible to noise, understanding stability is even more critical [12, 32]. Hence, in this work, we leverage dynamical systems theory to rigorously analyze the stability and convergence properties of predictive coding networks (PCNs). Our contributions are as follows:

  • â€¢

    Derivation of Stability Bounds: We derive tight stability bounds for PCNs using Lipschitz conditions on the activation functions. By leveraging these bounds, we establish that PCNs are Lyapunov stable, ensuring that their synaptic weight updates converge to a fixed point. This stability guarantees robustness to perturbations in the input, synaptic weights, and initial neuronal states, providing a formal foundation for the robustness properties of PCNs.

  • â€¢

    Quasi-Newton Approximation: We demonstrate that PC updates approximate quasi-Newton updates for synaptic parameters by incorporating higher-order curvature information. This property implies that PCNs require fewer update steps to achieve convergence compared to standard gradient descent, owing to the incorporation of second-order information, which adjusts both the direction and magnitude of gradient steps.

  • â€¢

    Theoretical Comparison with BP and Target Propagation: Using our developed framework, we derive novel bounds that quantify similarities between PC, backpropagation (BP), and target propagation (TP). These bounds explicitly capture the influence of higher-order derivatives, showing that PC is closer to quasi-Newton updates than TP, thereby providing a more refined understanding of its stability and efficiency relative to other learning schemes.

Our results establish a new theoretical foundation for PC as a robust and efficient learning framework, offering insights into its convergence properties and stability advantages over traditional learning methods. To this end, in the following section we will both introduce some background on PCNs, as well as defining concepts from the dynamical systems theory that will be used to prove our results.

2 Background and Motivation

Predictive coding networks (PCNs) are hierarchical neural networks, structurally similar to multi-layer perceptrons, that perform approximate Bayesian inference and adapt parameters by minimizing a variational free energy functional [33, 9, 13]. A PCN consists of Lğ¿Litalic_L layers with neural activities {x0,x1,â€¦,xL}subscriptğ‘¥0subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ¿\{x_{0},x_{1},\dots,x_{L}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, where x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xLsubscriptğ‘¥ğ¿x_{L}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT correspond to the input and output signal, respectively. The goal of each layer is to predict the neural activities of the next layer via the parametric function fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1)ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1f(W_{l}x_{l-1})italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where Wlsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™W_{l}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a weight matrix that represents a linear map, and fğ‘“fitalic_f is a nonlinear activation function. The difference between the predicted and actual neural activities is referred to as the prediction error, formally defined and denoted as Ïµl=xlâˆ’fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1\epsilon_{l}=x_{l}-f(W_{l}x_{l-1})italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). During model training, the goal of a PCN is to minimize the total summation of (squared) prediction errors, expressed via the following variational free energy:

F=âˆ‘l=0LEl=âˆ‘l=0L|Ïµl|2,ğ¹superscriptsubscriptğ‘™0ğ¿subscriptğ¸ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘™0ğ¿superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™2F=\sum_{l=0}^{L}E_{l}=\sum_{l=0}^{L}|\epsilon_{l}|^{2},italic_F = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (1)

where El=|Ïµl|2subscriptğ¸ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™2E_{l}=|\epsilon_{l}|^{2}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents the local energy at neuronal layer lğ‘™litalic_l. This decomposition in terms of layer-wise energy functionals is what allows every update to be performed using local information only (i.e., only pre-synaptic and post-synaptic neural activity values), regardless of the fact that the updates rely on gradients. In supervised learning, the input layer x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is clamped to the data dğ‘‘ditalic_d whereas the output layer xLsubscriptğ‘¥ğ¿x_{L}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is clamped to the target Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. The free energy then decomposes into the loss at the output layer and the residual energy of hidden layers:

(2)

Minimizing the free energy functional Fğ¹Fitalic_F in PCNs is then accomplished through two distinct phases: inference and learning. During the inference phase, the activations of the hidden neuronal layers, denoted by x1,â€¦,xLâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ¿1{x_{1},\dots,x_{L-1}}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are iteratively updated so as to minimize Fğ¹Fitalic_F, while the activation values at the input layer x0subscriptğ‘¥0x_{0}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and output layer xLsubscriptğ‘¥ğ¿x_{L}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are held fixed to the values of the input data and target output, respectively. The dynamics governing the inference updates for each hidden layer are as follows:

Î”â¢xl=âˆ’âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xl=âˆ’Ïµl+Wl+1âŠ¤â¢(Ïµl+1âŠ™fâ€²â¢(Wl+1â¢xl)),forÂ â¢l=1,â€¦,Lâˆ’1,formulae-sequenceÎ”subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™1topdirect-productsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™1superscriptğ‘“â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™forÂ ğ‘™1â€¦ğ¿1\Delta x_{l}=-\frac{\partial F}{\partial x_{l}}=-\epsilon_{l}+W_{l+1}^{\top}% \left(\epsilon_{l+1}\odot f^{\prime}(W_{l+1}x_{l})\right),\quad\text{for }l=1,% \dots,L-1,roman_Î” italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = - italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ™ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , for italic_l = 1 , â€¦ , italic_L - 1 , (3)

where Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· denotes the learning rate.

2.1 Dynamical Systems Background

In this section, we outline the key concepts of stability and robustness taken from dynamical systems theory; these are essential for analyzing the behavior of neural networks and their corresponding learning algorithms. Understanding these concepts further allows us to characterize the performance and reliability of different models in terms of their dynamical properties. Note that the definitions stated here are not rigorous, due to a lack of space needed to properly define all the details, and notation. Readers interested in the formal definitions, used to be formally prove the theorems of this work, should refer to the supplementary material.

Firstly, we characterize what it means for a dynamical system to be stable.

Definition 2.1.

A dynamical system is said to be stable if, for any given Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exists a Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 such that if the initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) is within Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ of an equilibrium point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., |xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—|<Î´ğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¿|x(0)-x^{*}|<\delta| italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | < italic_Î´), then the state xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) remains within Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ of xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0 (i.e., |xâ¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—|<Ïµğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥italic-Ïµ|x(t)-x^{*}|<\epsilon| italic_x ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | < italic_Ïµ for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0).

We further consider comparing stability between two dynamical systems, defining conditions under which one system is considered more stable than another.

Definition 2.2.

Let Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be two dynamical systems with equilibrium points xDâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·x^{*}_{D}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xDâ€²âˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. The system Dğ·Ditalic_D is said to be more stable than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for the same perturbation or initial deviation from equilibrium, Dğ·Ditalic_D either:

  • (i)

    Converges to its equilibrium point faster than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  • (ii)

    Remains closer to its equilibrium point over time, or,

  • (iii)

    Has a larger region of attraction, indicating greater tolerance to perturbations.

Next, we define the key dynamical systems analysis concept of a system reaching a fixed point.

Definition 2.3.

A point xâˆ—âˆˆâ„nsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘›x^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called a fixed point or equilibrium point of the dynamical system xË™â¢(t)=fâ¢(xâ¢(t))Ë™ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\dot{x}(t)=f(x(t))overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t ) = italic_f ( italic_x ( italic_t ) ) if fâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0f(x^{*})=0italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. The system is said to converge to the fixed point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for initial states xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) in a neighborhood of xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the trajectories satisfy limtâ†’âˆxâ¢(t)=xâˆ—subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥\lim_{t\to\infty}x(t)=x^{*}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ( italic_t ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Lastly, we address the rate of convergence between two stable dynamical systems, which can be used to measure convergence bounds for deep neural networks.

Definition 2.4.

Let Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be dynamical systems that converge to the same fixed point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We say that Dğ·Ditalic_D converges faster than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for initial conditions close to xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the distance to the fixed point decreases at a higher rate for Dğ·Ditalic_D compared to Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2.1.1 Robustness to Perturbations and Lyapunovâ€™s Stability

Beyond stability, robustness refers to a systemâ€™s ability to maintain performance in the presence of disturbances or uncertainties. Robust systems can handle variations without significant degradation, which is critical for practical applications. This notion can be defined as follows:

Definition 2.5.

A dynamical system is said to be robust to random perturbations if, for any small random perturbation Î·â¢(t)ğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta(t)italic_Î· ( italic_t ) acting on the system, the perturbed state xÎ·â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‚ğ‘¡x_{\eta}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) remains close to the unperturbed state xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) with high probability for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0. This implies that the system can maintain its desired performance despite small random disturbances.

Similarly, robustness with respect to initial conditions ensures consistent system behavior even when starting from a range of possible initial states due to uncertainties or randomness.

Definition 2.6.

A dynamical system is said to be robust to random initial conditions if, given initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) drawn from a probability distribution with bounded support, the systemâ€™s state xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) remains close to the desired trajectory or equilibrium point xâˆ—â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{*}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) with high probability for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0.

Robustness is particularly important in artificial neural networks (ANNs) operating in real-world environments, where inputs and initial conditions can vary unpredictably. Applying these concepts to neural networks, Lyapunovâ€™s methods provide tools for assessing whether small changes in weights or inputs lead to small changes in outputs, which is crucial for ensuring reliable learning and inference. To this end, we now introduce the important definition of Lyapunov stability:

Definition 2.7.

An ANN is Lyapunov stable if, for any given Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exists a Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 such that if initial weights Wâ¢(0)ğ‘Š0W(0)italic_W ( 0 ) are within Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ of a trained equilibrium point Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., |Wâ¢(0)âˆ’Wâˆ—|<Î´ğ‘Š0superscriptğ‘Šğ›¿|W(0)-W^{*}|<\delta| italic_W ( 0 ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | < italic_Î´), then the weights Wâ¢(t)ğ‘Šğ‘¡W(t)italic_W ( italic_t ) remain within Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ of Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0 (i.e., |Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—|<Ïµğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šitalic-Ïµ|W(t)-W^{*}|<\epsilon| italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | < italic_Ïµ for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0). If, in addition, the weights converge to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\inftyitalic_t â†’ âˆ, then the ANN is said to be asymptotically stable.

3 Theoretical Results

In this section, we study the convergence and stability of PCNs by leveraging the framework of dynamical systems and Lyapunov stability theory established above. We establish a series of theorems that states that, if activation functions and their higher-order derivatives are Lipschitz continuous, PCNs converge to Lyapunov stable equilibrium points. These results are then used to compare convergence speed of PCNs against backpropagation (BP) updates. Note that such a condition on the activations excludes linear rectifiers (ReLUs) yet includes oft-used ones such as the logistic sigmoid, the hyperbolic tangent (tanh), and the newly proposed TeLU [34].

The following theorem provides a characterization of the convergence and stability of the PCN based on the properties of these types of functions (proof in the appendix).

Theorem 3.1.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a PCN that minimizes a free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backprop loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants Kğ¾Kitalic_K, Kâ€²superscriptğ¾â€²K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Kâ€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the convergence and stability of the PCN can be characterized by the bounds involving these higher-order derivatives.

The above shows that if a PCN uses activations that are smooth and well-behaved (i.e., they and their first few derivatives change gradually without sudden spikes), then the network will converge reliably and maintain stability during training.

The next theorem crucially connects PCNs with continuous-time dynamical systems, facilitating analysis of their behavior with the plethora of tools of dynamical systems theory. Usefully, the result below effectively establishes that the dynamics of the neuronal layers (the E-steps [35]) that make up PCNs do converge to equilibrium points

Theorem 3.2.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a PCN that minimizes a free energy function F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backprop loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume that Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite, and their sum Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) has a strict minimum at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Fâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥0F(x^{*})=0italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. Further, assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime}italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PCN dynamics can be represented as a continuous-time dynamical system, and the Lyapunov function Vâ¢(x)=Fâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥V(x)=F(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_F ( italic_x ) ensures convergence to the equilibrium x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Theorem 3.2 establishes the stability and convergence properties of a PCN that minimizes the variational free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG. The conditions assumed are that both Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite, meaning they are zero only at a unique equilibrium x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€“ where Fâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥0F(x^{*})=0italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 â€“ and are strictly positive otherwise. The theorem further states that the free energy function Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) can be used as a Lyapunov function, Vâ¢(x)=Fâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥V(x)=F(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_F ( italic_x ), to analyze the PCNâ€™s behavior as a continuous-time dynamical system. Since Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) is positive definite and decreases along the systemâ€™s trajectories, it implies that the system will converge stably to the equilibrium point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT during training. Additionally, the smoothness assumptions on the activation fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives (up to second order, i.e., fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) being Lipschitz continuous ensures that the updates are stable and do not lead to erratic behavior (proof/assumptions in the appendix). The importance of this result is that it provides a formal guarantee for the convergence of PCNs, even in complex multi-layered networks.

The following result formally establishes that the parameter updates (M-steps) [35], governed by Equation 4, reliably converge to a fixed point of the variational free energy function. This convergence is a consequence of the underlying dynamics of PCNs, where the state variables xğ‘¥xitalic_x are first optimized to minimize the free energy Fğ¹Fitalic_F during inference, and subsequently, the weight parameters Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W are updated to reflect these optimal states.

In a PCN, the state optimization operates on a faster timescale compared to parameter optimization. The minimization of Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) with respect to xğ‘¥xitalic_x stabilizes the network states, ensuring that the networkâ€™s predictions are aligned with observations. Once the states converge to a local minimum, the parameter update described in EquationÂ equationÂ 4 ensures that the weights Wlsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™W_{l}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are adjusted based on the residual prediction errors Ïµlsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™\epsilon_{l}italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, the optimization of state variables xğ‘¥xitalic_x indirectly guides the optimization of weight parameters Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W.

In other words, state optimization stabilizes the neural activities to minimize the free energy while parameter optimization then adjusts the PCN weights based on these stable activations; this ensures convergence of the overall free energy to a global minimum. This hierarchical optimization strategy leads to the reliable convergence of both the states and weights in PCNs. Notably, this two-phase convergence (the result of a dual-phase optimization) highlights the interplay between fast state dynamics and slower weight dynamics, leading to Lyapunov stability in the parameter updates and further ensuring that both states and weights reach an optimal configuration.

Theorem 3.3.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a PCN that minimizes a free energy function F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backpropagation loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume that Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite functions and their sum Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) has a strict minimum at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, assume activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime}italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PCN updates are Lyapunov stable and converge to a fixed point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Note: In the above theorem (as well as in the rest throughout this work), xğ‘¥xitalic_x represents the internal state variables of the predictive coding network (PCN) rather than the input features normally presented to a traditional ANN.

This theorem provides a rigorous guarantee of stability and convergence of a PCN that minimizes the variational free energy Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ). Again, this result assumes that both Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite functions, meaning that they are zero only at the equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and strictly positive elsewhere. This ensures that their combination Fâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥F(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) also reaches its strict minimum value at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Theorem 3.3 further requires that the activation fğ‘“fitalic_f and its higher-order derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous, which guarantees smooth changes in these functions without sudden spikes/oscillations. By treating Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) as a Lyapunov function, the positive definiteness and monotonic decrease of Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) along the trajectories of the system imply that the updates are Lyapunov stable, meaning that any small perturbations to the system will not cause instability. Consequently, the PCN is guaranteed to converge to the unique equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as training progresses.

Finally, our last theorem establishes a comparison in terms of convergence speed to fixed points between PCNs and the popular workhorse training algorithm of deep neural networks, backprop (BP). Crucially, our result formally shows that, assuming both PCNs and BP-trained networks start from the same ideal initial conditions, PCNs converge faster â€“ in terms of number of needed parameter updates â€“ to fixed points than equivalent neuronal systems trained via BP.

Theorem 3.4.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a PCN that minimizes a free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backpropagation loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²,ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime},italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PCN updates are Lyapunov stable and converge to a fixed point faster than BP updates.

Here, in establishing that a PCN minimizer of Fğ¹Fitalic_F is Lyapunov stable, the convergence behavior is analyzed under the assumption that the activation fğ‘“fitalic_f (and derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) is Lipschitz continuous (ensuring smooth, controlled changes in these functions). The significance of this result lies in showing that PCN dynamics can achieve a stable equilibrium point with faster convergence due to the inclusion of the residual energy E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG. This term captures complex dependencies between layers, providing additional regularization and smoothing to the gradient flow, further aiding to reduce oscillations and accelerating convergence (compared to BP). In interpreting Fğ¹Fitalic_F as a Lyapunov function (as before, this allowed us to prove guaranteed convergence to a unique equilibrium), we see that the E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG introduces a corrective mechanism, which ensures that the PCN reaches its fixed point more efficiently than BP, making it particularly useful for training deep networks where standard BP may suffer from slower convergence/instability (proof/derivations in appendix).

Taken together, the above results rigorously demonstrate, from a dynamical systems perspective, why PCNs tend to quickly converge to stable solutions as compared to BP. This rapid convergence, despite extra computational complexity incurred by an EM-like optimization, is well-supported by a body of experimental evidence [15, 21, 22].

3.1 Robustness Analysis

Next, we turn to our result to formally characterize the robustness of PCNs compared to BP-adapted networks. With Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) corresponding to the BP loss and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) representing the residual energy of the system, we are able to establish that a PCNâ€™s trajectory (through a loss surface) is Lyapunov stable. While BP (Backpropagation) optimizes Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) by directly minimizing the loss through gradient descent updates, PCNs take into account both Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ), resulting in a combined energy minimization that stabilizes the optimization path. This provides a theoretical justification for the improved robustness of PCNs, as the added residual energy E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) acts as a corrective term that smooths out abrupt changes in the gradient landscape, leading to a more gradual convergence.

Theorem 3.5.

Let VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) be a Lyapunov function, where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite functions that achieve their minimum at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the trajectories of the system, and the predictive coding updates seen as a continuous-time dynamical system are, respectively:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2â‰¤0,WË™l=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl),formulae-sequencesubscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š20subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}\leq 0,\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \dot{W}_{l}=-% \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W_{l% }}\right),overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0 , overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) , (5)

making the system Lyapunov stable. Furthermore, if VË™PCâ¢(W)=0subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š0\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = 0 only at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the predictive coding updates are asymptotically stable and converge to the equilibrium point W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To better understand how this relates to standard BP, let us now analyze the derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ). If the residual energy E~â¢(W)â†’0â†’~ğ¸ğ‘Š0\tilde{E}(W)\rightarrow 0over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) â†’ 0, the update rule reduces to:

WË™l=âˆ’âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl,subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}},overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

which is precisely the standard BP update. Thus, BP can be seen as a special case of PCNs where the residual energy term vanishes. However, in practical scenarios, E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) typically does not reach zero, allowing PCNs to maintain more stable trajectories through the loss landscape. This difference becomes evident in the Lyapunov stability analysis. Since E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) is a positive definite function, it introduces an additional stabilizing force in the gradient dynamics, ensuring that any perturbations in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W are corrected by E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ). This means that, unlike BP, which optimizes Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) alone, the combined energy minimization in PCNs results in a smoother convergence trajectory, reducing sensitivity to local minima and sharp changes in the loss surface.

Let us again consider VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ), where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite and achieve their minima at the equilibrium point W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This composite energy function serves as a Lyapunov function for the system, as shown in the above theorem. We now state a more powerful result that establishes the robustness of PCNs compared to BP.

Theorem 3.6 (Robustness of Predictive Coding Networks).

Let VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) be the Lyapunov function of a PCN, where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite functions that achieve their minima at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Assume the following conditions hold:

  1. 1.

    The Hessian of Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ), denoted as HL=âˆ‚2Lâˆ‚W2subscriptğ»ğ¿superscript2ğ¿superscriptğ‘Š2H_{L}=\frac{\partial^{2}L}{\partial W^{2}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, is positive semi-definite.

  2. 2.

    The residual energy term E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) satisfies a Lipschitz continuity condition, i.e., there exists a constant K>0ğ¾0K>0italic_K > 0 such that:

    â€–âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–â‰¤Kâ¢â€–Wâˆ’Wâˆ—â€–.norm~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ¾normğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Š\left\|\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|\leq K\left\|W-W^{*}\right\|.âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_K âˆ¥ italic_W - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ .
  3. 3.

    The time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the system trajectories satisfies equationÂ 5 (left).

  4. 4.

    The initial perturbation Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W is small, i.e., â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–â‰ª1much-less-thannormÎ”ğ‘Š1\|\Delta W\|\ll 1âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ â‰ª 1.

Under these conditions, the following robustness property holds for PCNs:

Bounded Perturbation Recovery: For any perturbation Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W such that W=Wâˆ—+Î”â¢Wğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘ŠW=W^{*}+\Delta Witalic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Î” italic_W, the PCNâ€™s weight trajectory Wâ¢(t)ğ‘Šğ‘¡W(t)italic_W ( italic_t ) satisfies:

â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–â‰¤Câ¢eâˆ’Î»â¢tâ¢â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–+Oâ¢(Ïµ),normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šğ¶superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡normÎ”ğ‘Šğ‘‚italic-Ïµ\|W(t)-W^{*}\|\leq Ce^{-\lambda t}\|\Delta W\|+O(\epsilon),âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_C italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ + italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) ,

where constants C,Î»>0ğ¶ğœ†0C,\lambda>0italic_C , italic_Î» > 0 depend on properties of Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ); Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ is perturbation magnitude. This result guarantees exponential convergence to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and robustness to bounded perturbations.

Effectively, these results establish that PCNs reliably converge to equilibrium points of the loss function when optimizing their variational free energy, and once they do, the parameters will remain near those points indefinitely, highlighting the robustness of PCNs.

Robustness Comparison between PC and BP. As one may observe above, a core difference between a BP-based network and a PCN is their underlying optimization objective â€“ BP optimizes just Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) whereas a PCN optimizes Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠL(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ). The central mechanism behind a PCNâ€™s effectiveness is its use of and focus on optimizing energy E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, which, as our results in Section 3 established, underwrites the PCNâ€™s ability to stably converge to fixed points (equilibrium). There are several consequences that come as a result of this crucial difference:

  • â€¢

    Separation Characteristic: For BP, robustness is characterized by the minimal separation characteristic, which can be improved but remains sensitive to input deviations. However, for PCNs, robustness is higher due to stabilization provided by residual energy E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG.

  • â€¢

    Error Handling: BP updates only consider the gradient of the loss function Lğ¿Litalic_L, which makes the resulting network models more prone to overfitting and less robust to perturbations. PCN updates, in contrast, consider both Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, ensuring smoother transitions and better handling of input deviations.

  • â€¢

    Convergence: BP updates can lead to oscillations or slower convergence due to their sensitivity to initial conditions and perturbations. On the other hand, PCN updates converge faster and more smoothly to equilibrium due to the damping effect of E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG.

Predictive Coding Updates as Quasi-Newton Updates

Quasi-Newton (QN) methods, such as BFGS optimization [36], iteratively update an approximation of the Hessian Hâˆ’1superscriptğ»1H^{-1}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, leading to more stable, faster converging updates compared to simple gradient descent. The Newton-Raphson update rule, for example, is given as follows:

Wt+1=Wtâˆ’Hâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(Wt)subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘¡W_{t+1}=W_{t}-H^{-1}\nabla L(W_{t})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

where Hğ»Hitalic_H is the Hessian matrix of the loss function Lğ¿Litalic_L. Notably, the weight updated performed by PC has been shown to approximate second-order optimization methods, specifically Gauss-Newton updates [21]. In this section, we extend this result by showing first that it is the residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG that modifies the gradient similarly to what the inverse Hessian does. Second, we connect this modification to QN updates, broadening the understanding of PC within this optimization framework. Finally, we compare the computed bounds against those obtained for target propagation (TP) [37], a popular biologically plausible learning algorithm for deep neural networks, and show that PC updates are much closer to QN updates as compared to TP, while converging faster to solutions. Let us start with the following:

Theorem 3.7.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a neural network that minimizes a free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the loss function and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²,fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime},f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²,ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime},italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PC updates approximate quasi-Newton updates by incorporating higher-order information through the residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG.

Given the above, let us now assume that we are faced with a learning task where we prefer using a stable training algorithm. As QN updates are well-known for their stability [36], we could favor one algorithm over another if the first better approximates such updates. Motivated by this, we next compare PC and TP, showing that the first better approximates QN updates:

Theorem 3.8.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a neural network minimizing a free energy function F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the loss function and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is a residual energy term. Let HGN=JTâ¢Jsubscriptğ»GNsuperscriptğ½ğ‘‡ğ½H_{\text{GN}}=J^{T}Jitalic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J denote the Gauss-Newton matrix, where Jğ½Jitalic_J is the Jacobian matrix of the networkâ€™s output with respect to the parameters. Consider the following update rules:

  • â€¢

    QN Update: Î”â¢WQN=âˆ’HGNâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)Î”subscriptğ‘ŠQNsuperscriptsubscriptğ»GN1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{QN}}=-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1}\nabla L(W)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ),

  • â€¢

    TP Update: Î”â¢WTP=âˆ’Blâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)Î”subscriptğ‘ŠTPsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘™1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{TP}}=-B_{l}^{-1}\nabla L(W)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ), where Blsubscriptğµğ‘™B_{l}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a block-diagonal approximation of the matrix HGNsubscriptğ»GNH_{\text{GN}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • â€¢

    PC Update: Î”â¢WPC=âˆ’(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢(âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W))Î”subscriptğ‘ŠPCsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{PC}}=-(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}\left(\nabla L(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)\right)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ).

Assume that Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) are twice differentiable, and the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives are Lipschitz continuous. Then, the approximation error between the updates and the true Quasi-Newton update satisfies EPCâ‰¤ETPsubscriptğ¸PCsubscriptğ¸TPE_{\text{PC}}\leq E_{\text{TP}}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where:

EPC=â€–Î”â¢WPCâˆ’Î”â¢WQNâ€–,ETP=â€–Î”â¢WTPâˆ’Î”â¢WQNâ€–.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¸PCnormÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠPCÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠQNsubscriptğ¸TPnormÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠTPÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠQNE_{\text{PC}}=\|\Delta W_{\text{PC}}-\Delta W_{\text{QN}}\|,\quad E_{\text{TP}% }=\|\Delta W_{\text{TP}}-\Delta W_{\text{QN}}\|.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

Thus, PC is mathematically closer to the true Quasi-Newton updates than TP.

The following theorem builds on the previous result and formally proves that PC reaches fixed points faster than TP, bolstering the value of PC bio-inspired learning over approaches such as TP.

Theorem 3.9.

Let DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represent two dynamical systems corresponding to predictive coding (PC) and target propagation (TP), respectively. Assume that both systems have the same equilibrium point Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the loss functions Lğ¿Litalic_L and residual energy E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are twice differentiable and positive definite. Furthermore, let the activation functions flsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘™f_{l}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and their derivatives be Lipschitz continuous. Define the Lyapunov functions:

  1. 1.

    For predictive coding: VPCâ¢(W)=Fâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=F(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_F ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ).

  2. 2.

    For target propagation: VTPâ¢(W)=âˆ‘l=1L12â¢â€–tlâˆ’flâ¢(Wlâ¢tlâˆ’1)â€–2subscriptğ‘‰TPğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿12superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™12V_{\text{TP}}(W)=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\frac{1}{2}\|t_{l}-f_{l}(W_{l}t_{l-1})\|^{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Then, it follows that PC is more stable than TP according to the following criteria:

  1. 1.

    Convergence Rate: DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges faster to its equilibrium point compared to DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Deviation from Equilibrium: DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exhibits a smaller deviation from the equilibrium compared to DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the same initial perturbation.

  3. 3.

    Region of Attraction: The region of attraction for DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is larger than that of DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The above highlights the fact that an important factor behind PCâ€™s successful ability to traverse to fixed-points reliably and stably is its ability to approximate the updates yielded by quasi-Newton methodology. This means that a PCNâ€™s optimization of its free energy functional affords it second-order information (without the typically prohibitive cost of computing the Hessian itself) in its traversal of a loss surface landscape. A desirable positive consequence of this sectionâ€™s results is that PC yields a better approximation of QN updates that the popular TP algorithm and, furthermore, PC-based learning is more stable than that of TP-centric adaptation (due to PCâ€™s ability to converge faster to equilibrium due to its smaller deviation from region of attractions in its loss surface).

4 Simulation Results

In this section, we provide empirical evidence related to some of the theoretical claims made by this work. First, we test convergence bounds for PC and BP, using an MSE loss, trained on MNIST and CIFAR10. Figures 1 and 2 show a custom convolution model (2 conv layer, 3 fc layer) trained on MNIST using TeLU and tanh activations. On MNIST, we see that PC converges faster than BP, even though both approaches reach similar performance; however, the different parameter updates of each yielded different trajectories. Similar findings are seen in Figure 3 for the CIFAR10-trained model.

Next, we conduct large-scale experiments. Specifically, we train multiple models on image classification tasks using PC, BP, and TP, as well as key variations, and report the number of epochs (which is proportional to the number of weight updates) needed to reach the best performance. Our computer simulations involved testing across across four widely-used image classification datasets, offering results for both useful digit and clothing object recognition but also for the case of more complex natural images: 1) MNIST, 2) Fashion-MNIST, 3) CIFAR10, and 4) CIFAR100. The variant algorithm methods included in our study were backprop (BP), predictive coding (PC) that optimizes a free energy functional made up of squared error losses PC-SE, predictive coding that optimizes a free energy functional composed of cross-entropy losses PC-CE, DDTP-Linear [39], DDTP-Control [39], and DTP-Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ [40].

Each model was trained for 100100100100 epochs using architectures designed for the characteristics of each dataset. Additionally, beside standard activation such as Tanh, ReLU, sigmoid we incorporated a novel activation function, the hyperbolic tangent exponential linear unit (TeLU) [34], in all experiments which offered better stability. Unlike ReLU, which lacks higher-order Lipschitz continuity, TeLU, Tanh and sigmoid ensures smooth transitions and stability even for higher-order derivatives, a property crucial for this paperâ€™s theoretical findings. This property proved particularly beneficial for the predictive coding (PC) and difference target propagation (DTP) methods, resulting in more stable, consistent convergence behavior than traditional activations (using Relu/Tanh, PC exhibited higher variance.

All of the models were optimized using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with momentum, specifically using a learning rate set to 0.0010.0010.0010.001 with a batch size 128128128128. For each method and dataset, we ran the experiments for 15151515 trials (with 15151515 different random seeds) and report the mean test accuracy and standard deviation (SD) corresponding to the epoch with the best validation error. The experiments were performed using PCX, a novel library introduced to perform experiments with and benchmark predictive coding networks [16]. A more detailed description of the models used, as well as the test accuracies reached during the experiments, is reported in TableÂ 2, while the the average number of epochs required for each algorithm to converge on the complex CIFAR-10 dataset is reported in TableÂ 2. Note that, in TableÂ 2, we investigated each algorithm used in tandem with either SGD, SGD with momentum (SGD+M), or RMSprop [41].

5 Conclusion

In this work, we conducted a rigorous study of the stability and robustness of the biological inference and learning framework known as predictive coding (PC). Concretely, we employed dynamical systems theory to show that PC networks (PCNs) are Lyapunov stable by specifically deriving tights bounds on the stability of PCNs equipped with Lipschitz activation functions, demonstrating that they are able to converge to fixed-points and further offer robustness to perturbations applied to sensory inputs, synaptic weight values, and initial neuronal state conditions. Furthermore, we were able to formally demonstrate that the updates yielded by PCN dynamics approximate quasi-Newton updates applied to synaptic connection strengths, uncovering that PCNs utilize second order information to adjust the direction and magnitude of the gradient steps that they carry out. Notably, our results usefully yielded tighter theoretical bounds on the approximations of other algorithms, such as backpropagation of errors and target propagation, that are yielded by predictive coding models.
