Appendix

In this appendix, we provide additional experimental details as well as the complete formalization/set of details underlying the definitions and theoretical results provided in this work, including the formal proofs behind the presented theorems.

Appendix A Experimental Details

In this section, in Table 3 (Left), we provide additional details with respect to the full specification of the model architectures utilized for our credit assignment algorithms in the main paperâ€™s simulations. Furthermore, we present hyper-parameter value settings used for each credit assignment algorithm in Table 3 (Right). Hyper-parameter search where conducted over optimizer(SGD, SGD+M, AdamW), learning rate ([0.1, 1e-4]) and activation ([Tanh, Sigmoid, TeLU, ReLU]).

Appendix B Definitions

In this section, we fully formalize the background section on dynamical systems, made more informal due to a lack of space. The theorems stated in the main body of the paper, and proved in the following sections, rely on the following definitions. We start by first characterizing what it means for a dynamic system to be stable. This is established by the following definition:

Definition B.1.

A dynamical system is said to be stable if, for any given Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exists a Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 such that if the initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) is within Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ of an equilibrium point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Î´normğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¿\|x(0)-x^{*}\|<\deltaâˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Î´), then the state xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) remains within Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ of xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0 (i.e., â€–xâ¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Ïµnormğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥italic-Ïµ\|x(t)-x^{*}\|<\epsilonâˆ¥ italic_x ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0).

Formally:

âˆ€Ïµ>0,âˆƒÎ´>0â¢such thatâ¢â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Î´âŸ¹â€–xâ¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Ïµâ¢for allâ¢tâ‰¥0.formulae-sequencefor-allitalic-Ïµ0ğ›¿0such thatnormğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¿normğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥italic-Ïµfor allğ‘¡0\forall\epsilon>0,\exists\delta>0\,\text{such that}\,\|x(0)-x^{*}\|<\delta% \implies\|x(t)-x^{*}\|<\epsilon\,\text{for all}\,t\geq 0.âˆ€ italic_Ïµ > 0 , âˆƒ italic_Î´ > 0 such that âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Î´ âŸ¹ âˆ¥ italic_x ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all italic_t â‰¥ 0 .

Next we compare stability between two dynamical systems and show conditions required to show one system is better compared to another, which is formally defined as follows:

Definition B.2.

Let Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be two dynamical systems with equilibrium points xDâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·x^{*}_{D}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xDâ€²âˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. We say that the dynamical system Dğ·Ditalic_D is more stable than the dynamical system Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for the same perturbation or initial deviation from the equilibrium, the system Dğ·Ditalic_D either:

  • (i)

    Converges to its equilibrium point faster than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., it has a higher convergence rate, or

  • (ii)

    Remains closer to its equilibrium point for all time, i.e., has a smaller deviation from the equilibrium for the same perturbation, or

  • (iii)

    Has a larger region of attraction, indicating a greater tolerance to perturbations.

Formally, consider two dynamical systems Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represented by the differential equations:

xË™D=fDâ¢(x),xË™Dâ€²=fDâ€²â¢(x),formulae-sequencesubscriptË™ğ‘¥ğ·subscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘¥subscriptË™ğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²subscriptğ‘“superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¥\dot{x}_{D}=f_{D}(x),\quad\dot{x}_{D^{\prime}}=f_{D^{\prime}}(x),overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ,

with equilibrium points xDâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·x^{*}_{D}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xDâ€²âˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. We define three criteria:

1. Convergence Rate: Dğ·Ditalic_D converges faster to xDâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·x^{*}_{D}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT compared to Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if there exists a constant Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0 such that, for initial conditions xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) close to xDâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·x^{*}_{D}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) close to xDâ€²âˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

â€–xDâ¢(t)âˆ’xDâˆ—â€–â‰¤eâˆ’Î»â¢tâ¢â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xDâˆ—â€–,â€–xDâ€²â¢(t)âˆ’xDâ€²âˆ—â€–â‰¥eâˆ’Î»â€²â¢tâ¢â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xDâ€²âˆ—â€–,withÎ»>Î»â€².formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡normğ‘¥0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ†â€²ğ‘¡normğ‘¥0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²withğœ†superscriptğœ†â€²\|x_{D}(t)-x^{*}_{D}\|\leq e^{-\lambda t}\|x(0)-x^{*}_{D}\|,\quad\|x_{D^{% \prime}}(t)-x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}\|\geq e^{-\lambda^{\prime}t}\|x(0)-x^{*}_{D^{% \prime}}\|,\quad\text{with}\quad\lambda>\lambda^{\prime}.âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , with italic_Î» > italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

2. Region of Attraction: Dğ·Ditalic_D has a larger region of attraction if the set of initial points that converge to xDâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·x^{*}_{D}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, denoted as â„›Dsubscriptâ„›ğ·\mathcal{R}_{D}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, satisfies:

â„›DâŠ‡â„›Dâ€².subscriptâ„›superscriptğ·â€²subscriptâ„›ğ·\mathcal{R}_{D}\supseteq\mathcal{R}_{D^{\prime}}.caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‡ caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

3. Deviation from Equilibrium: For the same initial deviation â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xDâˆ—â€–=â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xDâ€²âˆ—â€–normğ‘¥0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·normğ‘¥0subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²\|x(0)-x^{*}_{D}\|=\|x(0)-x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}\|âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥, the system Dğ·Ditalic_D satisfies:

â€–xDâ¢(t)âˆ’xDâˆ—â€–â‰¤â€–xDâ€²â¢(t)âˆ’xDâ€²âˆ—â€–,âˆ€tâ‰¥0.formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ·normsubscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²for-allğ‘¡0\|x_{D}(t)-x^{*}_{D}\|\leq\|x_{D^{\prime}}(t)-x^{*}_{D^{\prime}}\|,\quad% \forall t\geq 0.âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , âˆ€ italic_t â‰¥ 0 .

If any of these criteria are met, then we say that Dğ·Ditalic_D is more stable than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Next we show important property of a system reaching fixed point, which is formally defined as follows:

Definition B.3.

Let xâ¢(t)âˆˆâ„nğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘›x(t)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x ( italic_t ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the state of a dynamical system at time tğ‘¡titalic_t, governed by the differential equation:

xË™â¢(t)=fâ¢(xâ¢(t)),Ë™ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\dot{x}(t)=f(x(t)),overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ( italic_t ) = italic_f ( italic_x ( italic_t ) ) ,

with f:â„nâ†’â„n:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›f:\mathbb{R}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a continuous function. A point xâˆ—âˆˆâ„nsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘›x^{*}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called a fixed point or equilibrium point of the system if fâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0f(x^{*})=0italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. The system is said to converge to the fixed point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for any initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) in a neighborhood ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N}caligraphic_N of xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the trajectory xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) satisfies:

limtâ†’âˆxâ¢(t)=xâˆ—.subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥\lim_{t\to\infty}x(t)=x^{*}.roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ( italic_t ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

More formally, for a neighborhood ğ’©âŠ†â„nğ’©superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{N}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}caligraphic_N âŠ† blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there exists a constant Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 such that if â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Î´normğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥ğ›¿\|x(0)-x^{*}\|<\deltaâˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Î´, then:

limtâ†’âˆxâ¢(t)=xâˆ—.subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥\lim_{t\to\infty}x(t)=x^{*}.roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ( italic_t ) = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

If the above holds for every initial condition xâ¢(0)âˆˆâ„nğ‘¥0superscriptâ„ğ‘›x(0)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_x ( 0 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is said to be a globally stable fixed point.

Next we formally define rate of convergence between two stable dynamical systems and how can be used to measure convergence bound for a network, which is defined as follows:

Definition B.4.

Let Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be dynamical systems that converge to the same fixed point xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT given the same initial conditions. Let xDâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘¡x_{D}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) and xDâ€²â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¡x_{D^{\prime}}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) denote the trajectories of the systems Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively, starting from the same initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ). We say that Dğ·Ditalic_D converges faster than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for any initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) sufficiently close to xâˆ—superscriptğ‘¥x^{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the distance to the fixed point decreases at a higher rate for Dğ·Ditalic_D compared to Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Formally, Dğ·Ditalic_D converges faster than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if there exists a positive constant Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0 such that for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0:

â€–xDâ¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–â‰¤Câ¢eâˆ’Î»â¢tâ¢â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–,andâ€–xDâ€²â¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–â‰¥Câ€²â¢eâˆ’Î»â€²â¢tâ¢â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–,withÎ»>Î»â€²,formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ¶superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡normğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥andformulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ†â€²ğ‘¡normğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥withğœ†superscriptğœ†â€²\|x_{D}(t)-x^{*}\|\leq Ce^{-\lambda t}\|x(0)-x^{*}\|,\quad\text{and}\quad\|x_{% D^{\prime}}(t)-x^{*}\|\geq C^{\prime}e^{-\lambda^{\prime}t}\|x(0)-x^{*}\|,% \quad\text{with}\quad\lambda>\lambda^{\prime},âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_C italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ , and âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ , with italic_Î» > italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where C,Câ€²>0ğ¶superscriptğ¶â€²0C,C^{\prime}>0italic_C , italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 are positive constants and Î»,Î»â€²ğœ†superscriptğœ†â€²\lambda,\lambda^{\prime}italic_Î» , italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent the exponential convergence rates of the systems Dğ·Ditalic_D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively.

Alternatively, for non-exponential convergence, Dğ·Ditalic_D converges faster than Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exist times TD,TDâ€²>0subscriptğ‘‡ğ·subscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ·â€²0T_{D},T_{D^{\prime}}>0italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 such that:

TDâ‰¤TDâ€²andâ€–xDâ¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Ïµfor allâ¢tâ‰¥TD,â€–xDâ€²â¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â€–<Ïµfor allâ¢tâ‰¥TDâ€².formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‡ğ·subscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ·â€²andformulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥italic-Ïµformulae-sequencefor allğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ·formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ·â€²ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥italic-Ïµfor allğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ·â€²T_{D}\leq T_{D^{\prime}}\quad\text{and}\quad\|x_{D}(t)-x^{*}\|<\epsilon\quad% \text{for all}\,t\geq T_{D},\quad\|x_{D^{\prime}}(t)-x^{*}\|<\epsilon\quad% \text{for all}\,t\geq T_{D^{\prime}}.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all italic_t â‰¥ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all italic_t â‰¥ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Next we formally define robustness of a dynamical system

Definition B.5.

A dynamical system is said to be robust to random perturbations if, for any small random perturbation Î·â¢(t)ğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta(t)italic_Î· ( italic_t ) acting on the system, the perturbed state xÎ·â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‚ğ‘¡x_{\eta}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) remains close to the unperturbed state xâˆ—â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{*}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) with high probability for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0. This implies that the system can maintain its desired performance despite the presence of small random disturbances.

Formally, let xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) be the unperturbed state and xÎ·â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¥ğœ‚ğ‘¡x_{\eta}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) be the perturbed state of the system. The system is robust if, for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0 and any initial condition xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ), there exists a constant Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 and a probability threshold 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha1 - italic_Î±, such that if â€–Î·â¢(t)â€–<Î´normğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ›¿\|\eta(t)\|<\deltaâˆ¥ italic_Î· ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ < italic_Î´ for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0, then:

â„™â¢(suptâ‰¥0â€–xÎ·â¢(t)âˆ’xâ¢(t)â€–<Ïµ)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.â„™subscriptsupremumğ‘¡0normsubscriptğ‘¥ğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Ïµ1ğ›¼\mathbb{P}\left(\sup_{t\geq 0}\|x_{\eta}(t)-x(t)\|<\epsilon\right)\geq 1-\alpha.blackboard_P ( roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_x ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î± .

Next now we formally define what it means for a dynamical system to be robust to initial conditions.

Definition B.6.

A dynamical system is said to be robust to random initial conditions if, given an initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) drawn from a probability distribution ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with bounded support, the systemâ€™s state xâ¢(t)ğ‘¥ğ‘¡x(t)italic_x ( italic_t ) remains within a bounded region around its desired trajectory or equilibrium point xâˆ—â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{*}(t)italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) with high probability for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0.

Formally, let the initial state xâ¢(0)ğ‘¥0x(0)italic_x ( 0 ) be drawn from a distribution ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P with support Sğ‘†Sitalic_S such that â€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â¢(0)â€–â‰¤Mnormğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥0ğ‘€\|x(0)-x^{*}(0)\|\leq Mâˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_M for some M>0ğ‘€0M>0italic_M > 0. The system is robust if there exists a probability threshold 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha1 - italic_Î± such that for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exists a constant Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 satisfying:

â„™â¢(suptâ‰¥0â€–xâ¢(t)âˆ’xâˆ—â¢(t)â€–<Ïµ)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±wheneverâ€–xâ¢(0)âˆ’xâˆ—â¢(0)â€–â‰¤Î´.formulae-sequenceâ„™subscriptsupremumğ‘¡0normğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡italic-Ïµ1ğ›¼whenevernormğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘¥0ğ›¿\mathbb{P}\left(\sup_{t\geq 0}\|x(t)-x^{*}(t)\|<\epsilon\right)\geq 1-\alpha% \quad\text{whenever}\quad\|x(0)-x^{*}(0)\|\leq\delta.blackboard_P ( roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_x ( italic_t ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î± whenever âˆ¥ italic_x ( 0 ) - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_Î´ .
Definition B.7.

A neural network is said to be Lyapunov stable if, for any given Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exists a Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 such that if the initial weights Wâ¢(0)ğ‘Š0W(0)italic_W ( 0 ) are within Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ of a trained equilibrium point Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., â€–Wâ¢(0)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–<Î´normğ‘Š0superscriptğ‘Šğ›¿\|W(0)-W^{*}\|<\deltaâˆ¥ italic_W ( 0 ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Î´), then the weights Wâ¢(t)ğ‘Šğ‘¡W(t)italic_W ( italic_t ) remain within Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ of Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0 (i.e., â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–<Ïµnormğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šitalic-Ïµ\|W(t)-W^{*}\|<\epsilonâˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0).

If, in addition, the weights converge to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\inftyitalic_t â†’ âˆ, i.e.,

limtâ†’âˆâ€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–=0,subscriptâ†’ğ‘¡normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Š0\lim_{t\to\infty}\|W(t)-W^{*}\|=0,roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ = 0 ,

then the neural network is said to be asymptotically stable.

Example 1.

Why is Stability Important?

Stability is a fundamental property of neural networks, ensuring that small changes in the input or initial conditions do not cause large, unpredictable variations in the networkâ€™s output. Stability is crucial for both training and deployment. During training, instability can cause gradients to explode, leading to chaotic updates and preventing convergence. During deployment, an unstable network might produce drastically different outputs for minor input changes, undermining its reliability. In real-world scenarios where inputs are often noisy or slightly perturbed, a stable network can still produce accurate and consistent predictions, making it more reliable and robust.

Mathematical Insight:

Stability can be formally understood through the concept of *bounded sensitivity*. For a neural network f:â„nâ†’â„m:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘šf:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_f : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be stable, a small change in the input Î´â¢xğ›¿ğ‘¥\delta xitalic_Î´ italic_x should lead to a bounded change in the output. Mathematically, this is expressed as:

â€–fâ¢(x+Î´â¢x)âˆ’fâ¢(x)â€–â‰¤Kâ‹…â€–Î´â¢xâ€–,normğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ›¿ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥â‹…ğ¾normğ›¿ğ‘¥\|f(x+\delta x)-f(x)\|\leq K\cdot\|\delta x\|,âˆ¥ italic_f ( italic_x + italic_Î´ italic_x ) - italic_f ( italic_x ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_K â‹… âˆ¥ italic_Î´ italic_x âˆ¥ ,

for a constant K>0ğ¾0K>0italic_K > 0. A network is *stable* if Kğ¾Kitalic_K is small, implying that the network is not highly sensitive to input variations. A more refined way to analyze stability is through the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix Jfâ¢(x)subscriptğ½ğ‘“ğ‘¥J_{f}(x)italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ). If the largest eigenvalue Î»maxsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\max}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Jfâ¢(x)subscriptğ½ğ‘“ğ‘¥J_{f}(x)italic_J start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) satisfies Î»max<1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{\max}<1italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, then the system is considered to be stable because small perturbations in the input will decay rather than amplify as they propagate through the network.

Intuitive Example of Stability:

Consider a neural network trained for handwritten digit classification. If the network is stable, adding a small amount of Gaussian noise or slightly changing the position of a digit in the image (e.g., shifting the digit by a few pixels) will not cause the networkâ€™s prediction to change significantly. For example, a stable network will continue to classify a digit â€™8â€™ as â€™8â€™, even if the digit is slightly blurred or has a few pixels altered. This stability is essential for real-world applications where inputs are rarely perfect replicas of training data.

Detailed Example: Training a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN)

Stability becomes even more critical in Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) due to their sequential nature. Consider an RNN designed to predict the next word in a sentence. During training, if small changes in initial states or earlier inputs cause large deviations in hidden states, the RNN can produce completely different outputs, making training highly unstable. Mathematically, this corresponds to having a Jacobian matrix with eigenvalues greater than 1, which indicates that small errors will grow exponentially as they propagate through the network.

Counterexample: Non-Stable Systems and Vanishing/Exploding Gradients

Imagine training a deep feedforward network or an RNN without appropriate regularization. If the network is not stable, even small changes in the input or initial weights can lead to vanishing or exploding gradients, making learning ineffective. For example, in a deep RNN, an input sequence with slightly perturbed values might cause the gradients to either shrink to zero (vanishing gradient problem) or explode to very large values (exploding gradient problem), leading to poor model performance and unstable training.

Practical Implications of Stability:

1. Improved Training Dynamics: Stability ensures that gradient-based optimization methods produce smooth and predictable updates, enabling faster and more reliable convergence. 2. Reliable Predictions: In deployment, stable networks produce consistent outputs even with noisy or perturbed inputs, making them suitable for real-world applications like speech recognition or autonomous driving. 3. Control Over Adversarial Attacks: A stable network is less vulnerable to adversarial attacks, where small, carefully crafted input changes are designed to mislead the network into producing incorrect outputs.

Real-World Example: Stability in Financial Forecasting

Consider a neural network used for predicting stock prices. Financial data is inherently noisy and contains sudden fluctuations. If the network is unstable, even a slight change in the input features (e.g., a minor fluctuation in daily stock prices) could lead to drastically different predictions, making the network unreliable for decision-making. On the other hand, a stable network will produce consistent and reliable forecasts, ensuring that minor changes in the data do not cause significant shifts in the predictions.

Definition B.8.

A neural network is said to be robust to small random perturbations if, for any small random perturbation Î·â¢(t)ğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta(t)italic_Î· ( italic_t ) applied to its inputs or parameters, the networkâ€™s output yÎ·â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¦ğœ‚ğ‘¡y_{\eta}(t)italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) remains close to its unperturbed output yâˆ—â¢(t)superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡y^{*}(t)italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) with high probability for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0.

Formally, let yâ¢(t)ğ‘¦ğ‘¡y(t)italic_y ( italic_t ) be the nominal (unperturbed) output of the neural network and yÎ·â¢(t)subscriptğ‘¦ğœ‚ğ‘¡y_{\eta}(t)italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) be the output under random perturbations Î·â¢(t)ğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta(t)italic_Î· ( italic_t ). The network is said to be robust if, for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exists a constant Î´>0ğ›¿0\delta>0italic_Î´ > 0 and a probability threshold 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha1 - italic_Î±, such that if â€–Î·â¢(t)â€–<Î´normğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ›¿\|\eta(t)\|<\deltaâˆ¥ italic_Î· ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ < italic_Î´ for all tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0italic_t â‰¥ 0, then:

â„™â¢(suptâ‰¥0â€–yÎ·â¢(t)âˆ’yâˆ—â¢(t)â€–<Ïµ)â‰¥1âˆ’Î±.â„™subscriptsupremumğ‘¡0normsubscriptğ‘¦ğœ‚ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¦ğ‘¡italic-Ïµ1ğ›¼\mathbb{P}\left(\sup_{t\geq 0}\|y_{\eta}(t)-y^{*}(t)\|<\epsilon\right)\geq 1-\alpha.blackboard_P ( roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ ) â‰¥ 1 - italic_Î± .
Example 2.

Why is Robustness Important?

Robustness is a critical property for neural networks, especially in real-world applications, where input data is often noisy, contains slight perturbations, or deviates from the clean training data. A robust neural network maintains its accuracy and reliability even when faced with unexpected changes, ensuring consistent performance across diverse and challenging conditions. Robustness is crucial for safety-critical systems (e.g., autonomous vehicles, medical diagnosis), as failures can have significant real-world consequences.

Mathematical Intuition:

Robustness can be understood mathematically through the concept of *Lipschitz continuity*. For a neural network fğ‘“fitalic_f to be robust, small changes in the input should only cause small changes in the output. Formally, if fğ‘“fitalic_f is Kğ¾Kitalic_K-Lipschitz continuous, then for any two inputs xğ‘¥xitalic_x and xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

â€–fâ¢(x)âˆ’fâ¢(xâ€²)â€–â‰¤Kâ‹…â€–xâˆ’xâ€²â€–,normğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â€²â‹…ğ¾normğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â€²\|f(x)-f(x^{\prime})\|\leq K\cdot\|x-x^{\prime}\|,âˆ¥ italic_f ( italic_x ) - italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_K â‹… âˆ¥ italic_x - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ ,

where Kğ¾Kitalic_K is a constant that quantifies the networkâ€™s sensitivity to input variations. A small Kğ¾Kitalic_K implies that the network is less sensitive to input noise, thereby enhancing robustness. Robust networks minimize Kğ¾Kitalic_K and ensure that even adversarial or noisy inputs do not cause large deviations in the output, making them more reliable.

Intuitive Example of Robustness in Autonomous Driving:

Consider a neural network used for object detection in an autonomous vehicle. In ideal conditions, the network correctly identifies cars, pedestrians, and traffic signs. However, in real-world scenarios, the network must operate in varying lighting conditions (e.g., night vs. day), different weather (e.g., fog, rain), and even with potential sensor noise (e.g., camera blur, reflections).

If the network is robust, a slight distortion in a camera imageâ€”such as a shadow, slight rain droplets, or fogâ€”will not cause it to misclassify a pedestrian as a signpost or ignore a stop sign. The networkâ€™s ability to generalize well in the presence of such variations ensures safety and reliability.

Detailed Example: Image Classification under Adversarial Noise

Letâ€™s consider a neural network trained to classify handwritten digits from the MNIST dataset. If the network is only trained on clean images, adding small perturbations (e.g., random Gaussian noise) might lead to misclassification, even though a human observer would still recognize the digit.

To test robustness, we introduce small adversarial noise Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ to the input images such that the perturbed image is xâ€²=x+Î´superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¥ğ›¿x^{\prime}=x+\deltaitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x + italic_Î´. For a non-robust network, a minimal Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´ can cause the classification result to change drastically, even though â€–Î´â€–normğ›¿\|\delta\|âˆ¥ italic_Î´ âˆ¥ is small. A robust network, however, would maintain consistent outputs for both xğ‘¥xitalic_x and xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, implying that fâ¢(xâ€²)â‰ˆfâ¢(x)ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x^{\prime})\approx f(x)italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ italic_f ( italic_x ).

Counterexample: Non-Robust Systems in Medical Imaging

Consider a neural network designed to detect tumors in medical images. If the network is not robust, even slight variations in the inputâ€”such as minor differences in lighting or slight changes in the position of the patientâ€”could lead to incorrect classifications, potentially causing false positives or missing a critical diagnosis. In medical applications, where errors have life-threatening consequences, robustness is paramount.

Real-World Consequences of Non-Robustness

In safety-critical applications like autonomous driving or healthcare, a non-robust network can have catastrophic outcomes. For example, an autonomous vehicle that fails to detect a pedestrian due to a shadow or slight occlusion might cause an accident. Similarly, a non-robust medical diagnostic system could misinterpret scans due to slight noise, leading to misdiagnosis.

Definition B.9.

Let Nğ‘Nitalic_N and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be two neural networks with weight dynamics governed by the differential equations:

WË™Nâ¢(t)=FNâ¢(WNâ¢(t)),WË™Nâ€²â¢(t)=FNâ€²â¢(WNâ€²â¢(t)),formulae-sequencesubscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹ğ‘subscriptğ‘Šğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptË™ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¡subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘â€²subscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¡\dot{W}_{N}(t)=F_{N}(W_{N}(t)),\quad\dot{W}_{N^{\prime}}(t)=F_{N^{\prime}}(W_{% N^{\prime}}(t)),overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) , overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ,

where WNâ¢(t)subscriptğ‘Šğ‘ğ‘¡W_{N}(t)italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) and WNâ€²â¢(t)subscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¡W_{N^{\prime}}(t)italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) represent the weights of the networks Nğ‘Nitalic_N and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at time tğ‘¡titalic_t, respectively, and Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the common equilibrium point such that FNâ¢(Wâˆ—)=0subscriptğ¹ğ‘superscriptğ‘Š0F_{N}(W^{*})=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 and FNâ€²â¢(Wâˆ—)=0subscriptğ¹superscriptğ‘â€²superscriptğ‘Š0F_{N^{\prime}}(W^{*})=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0.

We say that the network Nğ‘Nitalic_N converges faster than the network Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for any initial weights WNâ¢(0)subscriptğ‘Šğ‘0W_{N}(0)italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) and WNâ€²â¢(0)subscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²0W_{N^{\prime}}(0)italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) sufficiently close to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there exists a positive constant Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0italic_Î» > 0 such that the following inequality holds:

â€–WNâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–â‰¤Câ¢eâˆ’Î»â¢tâ¢â€–WNâ¢(0)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–,â€–WNâ€²â¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–â‰¥Câ€²â¢eâˆ’Î»â€²â¢tâ¢â€–WNâ€²â¢(0)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–,withÎ»>Î»â€²,formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šğ¶superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡normsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘0superscriptğ‘Šformulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ¶â€²superscriptğ‘’superscriptğœ†â€²ğ‘¡normsubscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²0superscriptğ‘Šwithğœ†superscriptğœ†â€²\|W_{N}(t)-W^{*}\|\leq Ce^{-\lambda t}\|W_{N}(0)-W^{*}\|,\quad\|W_{N^{\prime}}% (t)-W^{*}\|\geq C^{\prime}e^{-\lambda^{\prime}t}\|W_{N^{\prime}}(0)-W^{*}\|,% \quad\text{with}\quad\lambda>\lambda^{\prime},âˆ¥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_C italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ , âˆ¥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¥ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ , with italic_Î» > italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where C,Câ€²>0ğ¶superscriptğ¶â€²0C,C^{\prime}>0italic_C , italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 are positive constants and Î»,Î»â€²ğœ†superscriptğœ†â€²\lambda,\lambda^{\prime}italic_Î» , italic_Î» start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent the exponential convergence rates of the systems Nğ‘Nitalic_N and Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively.

If the convergence is non-exponential, Nğ‘Nitalic_N is said to converge faster than Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if, for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0italic_Ïµ > 0, there exist times TN,TNâ€²>0subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ‘â€²0T_{N},T_{N^{\prime}}>0italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 such that:

TNâ‰¤TNâ€²andâ€–WNâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–<Ïµfor allâ¢tâ‰¥TN,â€–WNâ€²â¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–<Ïµfor allâ¢tâ‰¥TNâ€².formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ‘â€²andformulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šitalic-Ïµformulae-sequencefor allğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘formulae-sequencenormsubscriptğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šitalic-Ïµfor allğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡superscriptğ‘â€²T_{N}\leq T_{N^{\prime}}\quad\text{and}\quad\|W_{N}(t)-W^{*}\|<\epsilon\quad% \text{for all}\,t\geq T_{N},\quad\|W_{N^{\prime}}(t)-W^{*}\|<\epsilon\quad% \text{for all}\,t\geq T_{N^{\prime}}.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and âˆ¥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all italic_t â‰¥ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , âˆ¥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ < italic_Ïµ for all italic_t â‰¥ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Example 3.

Why is Fast Convergence Important?

Fast convergence is essential for neural networks because it significantly reduces the time and computational resources required to train complex models. In modern machine learning, where models often have millions or even billions of parameters, slow convergence can make training impractical or prohibitively expensive. Moreover, achieving faster convergence often means that the model can reach higher accuracy or better generalization in less time, making it more competitive in real-world applications. Fast convergence is particularly important for:

  • â€¢

    Large-scale datasets: Reducing convergence time on massive datasets (e.g., ImageNet, OpenWebText) can translate to days or even weeks saved during training.

  • â€¢

    Iterative model development: Faster convergence allows for rapid prototyping and testing, enabling researchers to experiment with more architectures and hyperparameters within the same timeframe.

  • â€¢

    Dynamic or real-time systems: In applications where models need to be frequently retrained (e.g., reinforcement learning in robotics, online learning in trading systems), fast convergence is a necessity rather than a luxury.

Mathematical Insight into Convergence Speed:

The convergence rate of an optimization algorithm is typically characterized by the decrease in the loss function Lğ¿Litalic_L over iterations. Formally, if Ltsubscriptğ¿ğ‘¡L_{t}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the loss at iteration tğ‘¡titalic_t, then the convergence rate is defined as:

Ltâˆ’Lâˆ—â‰¤Câ‹…eâˆ’Ïâ¢tfor some constantsÂ â¢C,Ï>0,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¿ğ‘¡superscriptğ¿â‹…ğ¶superscriptğ‘’ğœŒğ‘¡for some constantsÂ ğ¶ğœŒ0L_{t}-L^{*}\leq C\cdot e^{-\rho t}\quad\text{for some constants }C,\rho>0,italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_C â‹… italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some constants italic_C , italic_Ï > 0 ,

where Lâˆ—superscriptğ¿L^{*}italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal loss and ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï is the convergence rate. A higher ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï indicates faster convergence. Consider two algorithms:

1. Algorithm A with a high convergence rate ÏAsubscriptğœŒğ´\rho_{A}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that Ltâˆ’Lâˆ—â‰¤Câ‹…eâˆ’ÏAâ¢tsubscriptğ¿ğ‘¡superscriptğ¿â‹…ğ¶superscriptğ‘’subscriptğœŒğ´ğ‘¡L_{t}-L^{*}\leq C\cdot e^{-\rho_{A}t}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_C â‹… italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2. Algorithm B with a lower convergence rate ÏB<ÏAsubscriptğœŒğµsubscriptğœŒğ´\rho_{B}<\rho_{A}italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Even if both algorithms have the same starting point and are optimizing the same loss, Algorithm A will reach near-optimal performance exponentially faster than Algorithm B. This difference becomes dramatic when tğ‘¡titalic_t is large, making Algorithm A much more suitable for training deep neural networks.

Detailed Example: Training a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)

Consider a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) designed to classify images in the CIFAR-10 dataset. Letâ€™s analyze two scenarios:

1. Scenario 1: We use a standard Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) optimizer with a constant learning rate, which is known for slow convergence on non-convex functions. As a result, the network might require 300 epochs to reach an accuracy of 85

2. Scenario 2: We switch to a momentum-based variant of SGD or the Adam optimizer, both of which have adaptive learning rates and gradient scaling. This change allows the same CNN to reach 85

The significant difference in training time between these two scenarios can be quantified as follows: if each epoch takes 5 minutes to complete, Scenario 1 would take 25 hours, while Scenario 2 would take just over 8 hours. This not only saves time but also reduces computational costs, which is crucial for large-scale deployments.

Counterexample: Slow Convergence and Its Implications

Letâ€™s consider training a Transformer model for language modeling on a large corpus. Suppose that due to poor hyperparameter tuning (e.g., a suboptimal learning rate schedule), the convergence rate is so slow that it requires 10101010x more epochs to reach comparable performance. The consequences are as follows:

  • â€¢

    Higher computational cost: Training time may increase from 2 days to 20 days on a multi-GPU setup, inflating hardware costs.

  • â€¢

    Delayed deployment: In dynamic systems, delayed training means delayed responses to changes in the data distribution, making the model outdated by the time it is deployed.

  • â€¢

    Suboptimal performance: Slow convergence can sometimes lead to getting stuck in local minima or saddle points, resulting in a final model that performs worse than one trained with a faster-converging algorithm.

Real-World Example: Fine-Tuning a BERT Model

Consider fine-tuning a BERT model for a sentiment analysis task. Due to the size of the model and the complexity of the task, convergence can be slow. However, by using learning rate scheduling strategies such as a cosine decay or warm-up phase, we can speed up convergence significantly. Instead of taking 5 epochs to achieve 90

In practice, this difference translates to reduced training costs and faster model deployment. Moreover, faster convergence reduces the risk of overfitting, since the model spends less time oscillating around local minima.

Thus faster convergence in neural networks is not just a matter of training speedâ€”it impacts every stage of model development, from experimentation and prototyping to deployment and long-term maintenance. Thus, selecting optimizers and training strategies that promote fast convergence is crucial for efficient and effective deep learning.

Appendix C Theorems on the Stability of PC

C.1 Proof of Theorem 3.1

Theorem C.1.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a Predictive Coding Network (PCN) that minimizes a free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backpropagation loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants Kğ¾Kitalic_K, Kâ€²superscriptğ¾â€²K^{\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Kâ€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the convergence and stability of the PCN can be characterized by the bounds involving these higher-order derivatives.

Proof.

Consider the prediction error dynamics for the lğ‘™litalic_l-th layer in a PCN, defined as:

Ïµlâ¢(t)=xlâ¢(t)âˆ’fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1â¢(t)).subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1ğ‘¡\epsilon_{l}(t)=x_{l}(t)-f(W_{l}x_{l-1}(t)).italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) .

We perform a Taylor series expansion of fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1â¢(t))ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1ğ‘¡f(W_{l}x_{l-1}(t))italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) around the equilibrium point Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1)=fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)+fâ€²â¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â¢(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))+12â¢fâ€²â€²â¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â¢(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))2ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptğ‘“â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™112superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™12f(W_{l}x_{l-1})=f(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})+f^{\prime}(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})(W_{l}(x_{l-1}% -x_{l-1}^{*}))+\frac{1}{2}f^{\prime\prime}(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})(W_{l}(x_{l-1}-x_{% l-1}^{*}))^{2}italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
+16â¢fâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â¢(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))3+Oâ¢((Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))4).16superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™13ğ‘‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™14+\frac{1}{6}f^{\prime\prime\prime}(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})(W_{l}(x_{l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*}% ))^{3}+O((W_{l}(x_{l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*}))^{4}).+ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_O ( ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Define the residual terms:

R2=12â¢fâ€²â€²â¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â¢(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))2,R3=16â¢fâ€²â€²â€²â¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â¢(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))3.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘…212superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™12subscriptğ‘…316superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™13R_{2}=\frac{1}{2}f^{\prime\prime}(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})(W_{l}(x_{l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*})% )^{2},\quad R_{3}=\frac{1}{6}f^{\prime\prime\prime}(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})(W_{l}(x_% {l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*}))^{3}.italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The prediction error can then be expressed as:

Ïµlâ¢(t)=xlâ¢(t)âˆ’fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)âˆ’fâ€²â¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â¢(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))âˆ’R2âˆ’R3.subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptğ‘“â€²subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1subscriptğ‘…2subscriptğ‘…3\epsilon_{l}(t)=x_{l}(t)-f(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})-f^{\prime}(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})(W_{l% }(x_{l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*}))-R_{2}-R_{3}.italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) - italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

By the Lipschitz continuity assumptions, we have the following bound for Ïµlâ¢(t)subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘¡\epsilon_{l}(t)italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ):

â€–Ïµlâ¢(t)â€–â‰¤Kâ¢â€–xlâˆ’fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â€–+Kâ€²â¢â€–Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—)â€–+Kâ€²â€²â¢â€–(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))2â€–+Kâ€²â€²â€²â¢â€–(Wlâ¢(xlâˆ’1âˆ’xlâˆ’1âˆ—))3â€–.normsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™ğ‘¡ğ¾normsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptğ¾â€²normsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptğ¾â€²â€²normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™12superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™13\|\epsilon_{l}(t)\|\leq K\|x_{l}-f(W_{l}x_{l-1}^{*})\|+K^{\prime}\|W_{l}(x_{l-% 1}-x_{l-1}^{*})\|+K^{\prime\prime}\|(W_{l}(x_{l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*}))^{2}\|+K^{% \prime\prime\prime}\|(W_{l}(x_{l-1}-x_{l-1}^{*}))^{3}\|.âˆ¥ italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_K âˆ¥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - This completes the proof. âˆ

C.2 Proof of Theorem 3.2

Theorem C.2.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a Predictive Coding Network (PCN) that minimizes a free energy function F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backpropagation loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume that Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite, and their sum Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) has a strict minimum at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Fâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ¹superscriptğ‘¥0F(x^{*})=0italic_F ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. Further, assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime}italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PCN dynamics can be represented as a continuous-time dynamical system, and the Lyapunov function Vâ¢(x)=Fâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥V(x)=F(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_F ( italic_x ) ensures convergence to the equilibrium x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

Consider the prediction error dynamics in a PCN given by:

Ïµl=xlâˆ’fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1).subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1\epsilon_{l}=x_{l}-f(W_{l}x_{l-1}).italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

The objective of the PCN is to minimize the free energy function:

Fâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x),ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥F(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x),italic_F ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) ,

where Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) is the backpropagation loss and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) is the residual energy. To analyze the stability of this system, we introduce a Lyapunov function:

Vâ¢(x)=Fâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x).ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥V(x)=F(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x).italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_F ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) .

**Step 1: Verifying Positive Definiteness of Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x )**

For Vâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥V(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) to be positive definite, the following must hold:

1. Vâ¢(x)â‰¥0ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0V(x)\geq 0italic_V ( italic_x ) â‰¥ 0 for all xğ‘¥xitalic_x. 2. Vâ¢(x)>0ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0V(x)>0italic_V ( italic_x ) > 0 for xâ‰ xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x\neq x^{*}italic_x â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. 3. Vâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘¥0V(x^{*})=0italic_V ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0.

We assume that both Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite around x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This implies:

Lâ¢(x)>0andE~â¢(x)>0forxâ‰ xâˆ—,formulae-sequenceğ¿ğ‘¥0andformulae-sequence~ğ¸ğ‘¥0forğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥L(x)>0\quad\text{and}\quad\tilde{E}(x)>0\quad\text{for}\quad x\neq x^{*},italic_L ( italic_x ) > 0 and over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) > 0 for italic_x â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and

Lâ¢(xâˆ—)=0,E~â¢(xâˆ—)=0.formulae-sequenceğ¿superscriptğ‘¥0~ğ¸superscriptğ‘¥0L(x^{*})=0,\quad\tilde{E}(x^{*})=0.italic_L ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 , over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 .

Therefore, Vâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥V(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) satisfies Vâ¢(x)>0ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0V(x)>0italic_V ( italic_x ) > 0 for all xâ‰ xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x\neq x^{*}italic_x â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Vâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘¥0V(x^{*})=0italic_V ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. Thus, Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) is positive definite.

**Step 2: Time Derivative of Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x )**

The time derivative of Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) along the trajectories of the system is given by:

VË™â¢(x)=âˆ‚Vâˆ‚xâ‹…xË™.Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘‰ğ‘¥Ë™ğ‘¥\dot{V}(x)=\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\cdot\dot{x}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG .

Using the dynamical system equation:

xË™l=âˆ’âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xl=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚xl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚xl),subscriptË™ğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™\dot{x}_{l}=-\frac{\partial F}{\partial x_{l}}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{% \partial x_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial x_{l}}\right),overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ,

we have:

VË™â¢(x)=âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ‹…(âˆ’âˆ‚Fâˆ‚x)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ€–2.Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥â‹…ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ¹ğ‘¥2\dot{V}(x)=\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\cdot\left(-\frac{\partial F}{\partial x% }\right)=-\left\|\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG â‹… ( - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Since VË™â¢(x)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ€–2â‰¤0Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ¹ğ‘¥20\dot{V}(x)=-\left\|\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\right\|^{2}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) is non-increasing along the trajectories of the system.

**Step 3: Stability Analysis**

Because Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) is positive definite and VË™â¢(x)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ€–2â‰¤0Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ¹ğ‘¥20\dot{V}(x)=-\left\|\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\right\|^{2}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) decreases monotonically and reaches its minimum value at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This implies that the system is Lyapunov stable. Furthermore, VË™â¢(x)=0Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0\dot{V}(x)=0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = 0 if and only if âˆ‚Fâˆ‚x=0ğ¹ğ‘¥0\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}=0divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG = 0, which occurs at the equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Hence, the system converges to the equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, completing the proof. âˆ

C.3 Proof of Theorem 3.3

Theorem C.3.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a Predictive Coding Network (PCN) that minimizes a free energy function F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backpropagation loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume that Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite functions, and their sum Fâ¢(x)ğ¹ğ‘¥F(x)italic_F ( italic_x ) has a strict minimum at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime}italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PCN updates are Lyapunov stable and converge to a fixed point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

Consider the prediction error dynamics in a PCN defined as:

Ïµl=xlâˆ’fâ¢(Wlâ¢xlâˆ’1).subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ‘“subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™1\epsilon_{l}=x_{l}-f(W_{l}x_{l-1}).italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

The objective of the PCN is to minimize the free energy function:

Fâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x),ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥F(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x),italic_F ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) ,

where Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) is the backpropagation loss and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) is the residual energy. To analyze the stability of this system, we introduce a Lyapunov function:

Vâ¢(x)=Fâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x).ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥V(x)=F(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x).italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_F ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) .

**Step 1: Verifying Positive Definiteness of Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x )**

For Vâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥V(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) to be a valid Lyapunov function, it must be positive definite, which requires:

Vâ¢(x)>0for allâ¢xâ‰ xâˆ—andVâ¢(xâˆ—)=0.formulae-sequenceğ‘‰ğ‘¥0formulae-sequencefor allğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥andğ‘‰superscriptğ‘¥0V(x)>0\quad\text{for all}\,x\neq x^{*}\quad\text{and}\quad V(x^{*})=0.italic_V ( italic_x ) > 0 for all italic_x â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and italic_V ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 .

We assume that both Lâ¢(x)ğ¿ğ‘¥L(x)italic_L ( italic_x ) and E~â¢(x)~ğ¸ğ‘¥\tilde{E}(x)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) are positive definite around x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This means:

Lâ¢(x)>0andE~â¢(x)>0forâ¢xâ‰ xâˆ—,formulae-sequenceğ¿ğ‘¥0andformulae-sequence~ğ¸ğ‘¥0forğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥L(x)>0\quad\text{and}\quad\tilde{E}(x)>0\quad\text{for}\,x\neq x^{*},italic_L ( italic_x ) > 0 and over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) > 0 for italic_x â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and

Lâ¢(xâˆ—)=0,E~â¢(xâˆ—)=0.formulae-sequenceğ¿superscriptğ‘¥0~ğ¸superscriptğ‘¥0L(x^{*})=0,\quad\tilde{E}(x^{*})=0.italic_L ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 , over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0 .

Thus, Vâ¢(x)=Lâ¢(x)+E~â¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¥~ğ¸ğ‘¥V(x)=L(x)+\tilde{E}(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) = italic_L ( italic_x ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_x ) satisfies Vâ¢(x)>0ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0V(x)>0italic_V ( italic_x ) > 0 for all xâ‰ xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x\neq x^{*}italic_x â‰  italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Vâ¢(xâˆ—)=0ğ‘‰superscriptğ‘¥0V(x^{*})=0italic_V ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0.

**Step 2: Time Derivative of Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x )**

The time derivative of Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) along the trajectories of the system is given by:

VË™â¢(x)=âˆ‚Vâˆ‚xâ‹…xË™.Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥â‹…ğ‘‰ğ‘¥Ë™ğ‘¥\dot{V}(x)=\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\cdot\dot{x}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG .

Using the dynamical system equation:

xË™l=âˆ’âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xl=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚xl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚xl),subscriptË™ğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘™\dot{x}_{l}=-\frac{\partial F}{\partial x_{l}}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{% \partial x_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial x_{l}}\right),overË™ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ,

we obtain:

VË™â¢(x)=âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ‹…(âˆ’âˆ‚Fâˆ‚x)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ€–2.Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥â‹…ğ¹ğ‘¥ğ¹ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ¹ğ‘¥2\dot{V}(x)=\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\cdot\left(-\frac{\partial F}{\partial x% }\right)=-\left\|\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG â‹… ( - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Since VË™â¢(x)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ€–2â‰¤0Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ¹ğ‘¥20\dot{V}(x)=-\left\|\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\right\|^{2}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) is non-increasing along the trajectories of the system. This implies that the free energy Fğ¹Fitalic_F decreases monotonically until the system reaches the equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where âˆ‚Fâˆ‚x=0ğ¹ğ‘¥0\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}=0divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG = 0.

**Step 3: Establishing Stability and Convergence**

Because Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) is positive definite and VË™â¢(x)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Fâˆ‚xâ€–2â‰¤0Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ¹ğ‘¥20\dot{V}(x)=-\left\|\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}\right\|^{2}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, Vâ¢(x)ğ‘‰ğ‘¥V(x)italic_V ( italic_x ) decreases monotonically and reaches its minimum value at x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This implies that the system is Lyapunov stable.

Furthermore, VË™â¢(x)=0Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0\dot{V}(x)=0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) = 0 if and only if âˆ‚Fâˆ‚x=0ğ¹ğ‘¥0\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}=0divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x end_ARG = 0, which occurs at the equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Thus, as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\inftyitalic_t â†’ âˆ, VË™â¢(x)â†’0â†’Ë™ğ‘‰ğ‘¥0\dot{V}(x)\to 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG ( italic_x ) â†’ 0 and the system converges to the equilibrium point x=xâˆ—ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥x=x^{*}italic_x = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, completing the proof. âˆ

C.4 Proof of Theorem 3.4

Theorem C.4.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a Predictive Coding Network (PCN) that minimizes a free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the backpropagation loss and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²superscriptğ‘“â€²f^{\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²,ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime},italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PCN updates are Lyapunov stable and converge to a fixed point faster than BP updates.

Proof.

Stability Analysis of BP Updates. Consider the BP updates modeled as a continuous-time dynamical system:

WË™l=âˆ’âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl.subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}.overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

Define a Lyapunov function for the BP updates:

VBPâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W).subscriptğ‘‰BPğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘ŠV_{\text{BP}}(W)=L(W).italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) .

The time derivative of VBPsubscriptğ‘‰BPV_{\text{BP}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT along the trajectories of the system is:

VË™BPâ¢(W)=âˆ‚VBPâˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W)Tâ‹…âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ€–2.subscriptË™ğ‘‰BPğ‘Šâ‹…subscriptğ‘‰BPğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šâ‹…superscriptğ¿ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ¿ğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{BP}}(W)=\frac{\partial V_{\text{BP}}}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}=-% \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\right)^{T}\cdot\frac{\partial L}{\partial W% }=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Since VË™BPâ‰¤0subscriptË™ğ‘‰BP0\dot{V}_{\text{BP}}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, VBPsubscriptğ‘‰BPV_{\text{BP}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-increasing along the trajectories of the BP updates. This indicates that the BP updates are Lyapunov stable. However, the convergence rate depends on the norm of the gradient â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ€–normğ¿ğ‘Š\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\|âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥, which may oscillate or decrease slowly if Lğ¿Litalic_L is non-convex.

Stability Analysis of PC Updates Consider the PC updates modeled as a continuous-time dynamical system:

WË™l=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl).subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{% \partial W_{l}}\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) .

Define a Lyapunov function for the PC updates:

VPCâ¢(W)=Fâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W).subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=F(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W).italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_F ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) .

The time derivative of VPCsubscriptğ‘‰PCV_{\text{PC}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT along the trajectories of the system is:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ‚VPCâˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W)Tâ‹…(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W).subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šâ‹…superscriptğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{\partial V_{\text{PC}}}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}=-% \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right% )^{T}\cdot\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{% \partial W}\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) .

This simplifies to:
