VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Since VË™PCâ‰¤0subscriptË™ğ‘‰PC0\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, VPCsubscriptğ‘‰PCV_{\text{PC}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-increasing along the trajectories of the PC updates. The residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG captures higher-order dependencies between layers, which leads to a smoother and more stable gradient trajectory, helping to reduce oscillations.

Comparison of Convergence Rates. To compare the convergence rates of BP and PC updates, consider the difference in the time derivatives of VBPsubscriptğ‘‰BPV_{\text{BP}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and VPCsubscriptğ‘‰PCV_{\text{PC}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

VË™BP=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ€–2,VË™PC=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2.formulae-sequencesubscriptË™ğ‘‰BPsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š2subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{BP}}=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\right\|^{2},\quad% \dot{V}_{\text{PC}}=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde% {E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Since the PC updates include the additional residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, which contributes to damping and faster reduction in VË™PCsubscriptË™ğ‘‰PC\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have:

VË™PCâ‰¤VË™BP.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCsubscriptË™ğ‘‰BP\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}\leq\dot{V}_{\text{BP}}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Thus, the PC updates decrease the free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG more rapidly than the BP updates decrease the loss Lğ¿Litalic_L alone. This implies that the PC updates converge to the equilibrium point Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT faster than the BP updates.

Thus the presence of the residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG in the PC updates leads to a smoother and more stable update trajectory, resulting in faster convergence to the fixed point. Therefore, the PC updates are more stable and reach a fixed point earlier than BP updates. âˆ

Backprop Updates. In traditional backpropagation (BP), the weight updates are given by:

Î”â¢Wl=âˆ’Î·â¢âˆ‚Lâˆ‚WlÎ”subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğœ‚ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\Delta W_{l}=-\eta\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_Î· divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG

where Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is the learning rate and Lğ¿Litalic_L is the loss function. The update rule can be expressed in terms of stochastic gradient descent (SGD):

Wl(t+1)=Wl(t)âˆ’Î·â¢âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl.superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™W_{l}^{(t+1)}=W_{l}^{(t)}-\eta\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}.italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG .

PC Updates. In predictive coding, the weight updates are derived by minimizing the free energy functional F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG. The resulting update rule is:

Î”â¢Wl=âˆ’Î·â¢(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl)Î”subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğœ‚ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\Delta W_{l}=-\eta\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde% {E}}{\partial W_{l}}\right)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_Î· ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG )

which can further, much like in BP, can be cast in terms of an SGD adjustment:

Wl(t+1)=Wl(t)âˆ’Î·â¢(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl).superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™W_{l}^{(t+1)}=W_{l}^{(t)}-\eta\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{% \partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W_{l}}\right).italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) .

Appendix D Theorems on Robustness

Updates of BP

Consider the BP updates as a continuous-time dynamical system:

WË™l=âˆ’âˆ‚Lâˆ‚WlsubscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG

Introduce a Lyapunov function VBPâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰BPğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘ŠV_{\text{BP}}(W)=L(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ). The time derivative along the trajectories of the system is:

VË™BPâ¢(W)=âˆ‚VBPâˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W)Tâ‹…âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ€–2subscriptË™ğ‘‰BPğ‘Šâ‹…subscriptğ‘‰BPğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šâ‹…superscriptğ¿ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ¿ğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{BP}}(W)=\frac{\partial V_{\text{BP}}}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}=-% \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\right)^{T}\cdot\frac{\partial L}{\partial W% }=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

Since VË™BPâ‰¤0subscriptË™ğ‘‰BP0\dot{V}_{\text{BP}}\leq 0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0, VBPsubscriptğ‘‰BPV_{\text{BP}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT BP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-increasing, indicating that the BP updates are stable. However, the convergence rate depends on the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· and the curvature of the loss function Lğ¿Litalic_L.

Updates of PCNs

Consider the PC updates as a continuous-time dynamical system:

WË™l=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl)subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{% \partial W_{l}}\right)overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG )

Introduce a Lyapunov function VPCâ¢(W)=Fâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=F(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_F ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ). The time derivative along the trajectories of the system is:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ‚VPCâˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W)Tâ‹…(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W)subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šâ‹…superscriptğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{\partial V_{\text{PC}}}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}=-% \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right% )^{T}\cdot\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{% \partial W}\right)overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG )

This simplifies to:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

D.1 Proof of Theorem 3.5

Theorem D.1.

Consider the predictive coding updates as a continuous-time dynamical system:

WË™l=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl).subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{% \partial W_{l}}\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) .

Let VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) be a Lyapunov function, where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite functions that achieve their minimum at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the trajectories of the system is:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2â‰¤0,subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š20\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}\leq 0,overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0 ,

and the system is Lyapunov stable. Furthermore, if VË™PCâ¢(W)=0subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š0\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = 0 only at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the predictive coding updates are asymptotically stable and converge to the equilibrium point W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

Step 1: Defining the Lyapunov Function Consider the Lyapunov function defined as:

VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W),subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W),italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ,

where: 1. Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) is the backpropagation loss. 2. E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) is an auxiliary error or regularization term.

Assume that Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) are positive definite, i.e.,

Lâ¢(W)>0andE~â¢(W)>0for allâ¢Wâ‰ Wâˆ—,formulae-sequenceğ¿ğ‘Š0andformulae-sequence~ğ¸ğ‘Š0for allğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠL(W)>0\quad\text{and}\quad\tilde{E}(W)>0\quad\text{for all}\,W\neq W^{*},italic_L ( italic_W ) > 0 and over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) > 0 for all italic_W â‰  italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and Lâ¢(Wâˆ—)=0ğ¿superscriptğ‘Š0L(W^{*})=0italic_L ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0, E~â¢(Wâˆ—)=0~ğ¸superscriptğ‘Š0\tilde{E}(W^{*})=0over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0. Thus, VPCâ¢(W)>0subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Š0V_{\text{PC}}(W)>0italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) > 0 for Wâ‰ Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW\neq W^{*}italic_W â‰  italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and VPCâ¢(Wâˆ—)=0subscriptğ‘‰PCsuperscriptğ‘Š0V_{\text{PC}}(W^{*})=0italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0.

Step 2: Time Derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) The time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the trajectories of the system is given by:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=ddâ¢tâ¢VPCâ¢(W).subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{d}{dt}V_{\text{PC}}(W).overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) .

Using the chain rule, we have:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ‚VPCâˆ‚Wâ‹…dâ¢Wdâ¢t.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ‘‘ğ‘Šğ‘‘ğ‘¡\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{\partial V_{\text{PC}}}{\partial W}\cdot\frac{dW}% {dt}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG italic_d italic_W end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG .

Since VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ), its gradient is:

âˆ‚VPCâˆ‚W=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W.subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\frac{\partial V_{\text{PC}}}{\partial W}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{% \partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}.divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG .

Substitute dâ¢Wdâ¢tğ‘‘ğ‘Šğ‘‘ğ‘¡\frac{dW}{dt}divide start_ARG italic_d italic_W end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG from the weight update rule:

dâ¢Wdâ¢t=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W).ğ‘‘ğ‘Šğ‘‘ğ‘¡ğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\frac{dW}{dt}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{% \partial W}\right).divide start_ARG italic_d italic_W end_ARG start_ARG italic_d italic_t end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) .

Thus, we get:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W)â‹…(âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W)).subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…ğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right)\cdot\left(-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+% \frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right)\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) â‹… ( - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) ) .

The dot product of a vector with its negative is the negative squared norm of the vector:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Step 3: Stability Analysis Since â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2â‰¥0superscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š20\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}% \right\|^{2}\geq 0âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 for all Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, we have:

VË™PCâ¢(W)â‰¤0.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š0\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)\leq 0.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) â‰¤ 0 .

This shows that VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) is non-increasing along the trajectories of the system. If VË™PCâ¢(W)=0subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š0\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = 0 only at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the system is asymptotically stable and converges to the equilibrium point W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Thus, the predictive coding updates are Lyapunov stable and, under the given conditions, asymptotically stable. âˆ

D.2 Proof of Theorem 3.6

Theorem D.2.

Let VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) be a Lyapunov function, where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite functions that achieve their minimum at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the trajectories of the system, and the predictive coding updates seen as a continuous-time dynamical system are, respectively:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2â‰¤0,WË™l=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl),formulae-sequencesubscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š20subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}\leq 0,\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \dot{W}_{l}=-% \left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W_{l% }}\right),overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0 , overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) , (6)

making the system Lyapunov stable. Furthermore, if VË™PCâ¢(W)=0subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š0\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=0overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = 0 only at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the predictive coding updates are asymptotically stable and converge to the equilibrium point W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To better understand how this relates to standard BP, let us now analyze the derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ). If the residual energy E~â¢(W)â†’0â†’~ğ¸ğ‘Š0\tilde{E}(W)\rightarrow 0over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) â†’ 0, the update rule reduces to:

WË™l=âˆ’âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl,subscriptË™ğ‘Šğ‘™ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\dot{W}_{l}=-\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}},overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

which is precisely the standard BP update. Thus, BP can be seen as a special case of PCNs where the residual energy term vanishes. However, in practical scenarios, E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) typically does not reach zero, allowing PCNs to maintain more stable trajectories through the loss landscape.

This difference becomes evident in the Lyapunov stability analysis. Since E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) is a positive definite function, it introduces an additional stabilizing force in the gradient dynamics, ensuring that any perturbations in Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W are corrected by E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ). This means that, unlike BP, which optimizes Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) alone, the combined energy minimization in PCNs results in a smoother convergence trajectory, reducing sensitivity to local minima and sharp changes in the loss surface.

Now we establish stronger robustness bounds. Let Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) represent the standard BP loss and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) denote the residual energy term introduced by the predictive coding framework. We define the composite energy function as:

VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W),subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W),italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ,

where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite and achieve their minima at the equilibrium point W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This composite energy function serves as a Lyapunov function for the system, as shown in the above theorem. We now state a more powerful result that establishes the robustness of PCNs compared to BP.

Theorem D.3 (Robustness of Predictive Coding Networks).

Let VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) be the Lyapunov function of a PCN, where Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite functions that achieve their minima at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Assume the following conditions hold:

1. The Hessian of Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ), denoted as HL=âˆ‚2Lâˆ‚W2subscriptğ»ğ¿superscript2ğ¿superscriptğ‘Š2H_{L}=\frac{\partial^{2}L}{\partial W^{2}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, is positive semi-definite.

2. The residual energy term E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) satisfies a Lipschitz continuity condition, i.e., there exists a constant K>0ğ¾0K>0italic_K > 0 such that:

â€–âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–â‰¤Kâ¢â€–Wâˆ’Wâˆ—â€–.norm~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ¾normğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Š\left\|\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|\leq K\left\|W-W^{*}\right\|.âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_K âˆ¥ italic_W - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

3. The time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the system trajectories satisfies Equation (5) (left).

4. The initial perturbation Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W is small, i.e., â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–â‰ª1much-less-thannormÎ”ğ‘Š1\|\Delta W\|\ll 1âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ â‰ª 1.

Under these conditions, the following robustness property holds for PCNs:

Bounded Perturbation Recovery: For any perturbation Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W such that W=Wâˆ—+Î”â¢Wğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘ŠW=W^{*}+\Delta Witalic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Î” italic_W, the PCNâ€™s weight trajectory Wâ¢(t)ğ‘Šğ‘¡W(t)italic_W ( italic_t ) satisfies:

â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–â‰¤Câ¢eâˆ’Î»â¢tâ¢â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–+Oâ¢(Ïµ),normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šğ¶superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡normÎ”ğ‘Šğ‘‚italic-Ïµ\|W(t)-W^{*}\|\leq Ce^{-\lambda t}\|\Delta W\|+O(\epsilon),âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_C italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ + italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) ,

where C,Î»>0ğ¶ğœ†0C,\lambda>0italic_C , italic_Î» > 0 are constants that depend on the properties of Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ), and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ is the perturbation magnitude. This result guarantees exponential convergence to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and robustness to bounded perturbations.

Proof.

We start by defining the Lyapunov function VPCâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ), which is positive definite and achieves its minimum at W=Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW=W^{*}italic_W = italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Our goal is to analyze the stability of the system by considering the time derivative of VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) along the system trajectories. The time derivative is given by:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…ğ¿ğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šâ‹…~ğ¸ğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}+\frac{% \partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG .

Using the update rule for PCNs, we have:

WË™=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W).Ë™ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{W}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W% }\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) .

Substitute WË™Ë™ğ‘Š\dot{W}overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG into VË™PCâ¢(W)subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ):

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ‹…(âˆ’âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâˆ’âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W)+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ‹…(âˆ’âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâˆ’âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W).subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…ğ¿ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šâ‹…~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\cdot\left(-\frac{\partial L% }{\partial W}-\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right)+\frac{\partial\tilde% {E}}{\partial W}\cdot\left(-\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}-\frac{\partial\tilde% {E}}{\partial W}\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… ( - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… ( - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) .

Simplifying, we get:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2â‰¤0.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š20\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=-\left\|\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}\leq 0.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0 .

This inequality shows that VË™PCâ¢(W)subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) is non-positive, implying that VPCâ¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) is monotonically decreasing along the trajectories of the system, ensuring Lyapunov stability.

Next, we analyze the perturbation dynamics. Define the deviation Î”â¢W=Wâˆ’Wâˆ—Î”ğ‘Šğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘Š\Delta W=W-W^{*}roman_Î” italic_W = italic_W - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The time derivative of Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W is:

Î”â¢WË™=WË™=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W).Ë™Î”ğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{\Delta W}=\dot{W}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right).overË™ start_ARG roman_Î” italic_W end_ARG = overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) .

For small Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W, we use the linear approximation:

âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wâ‰ˆHLâ¢Î”â¢W,âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ‰ˆKâ¢Î”â¢W,formulae-sequenceğ¿ğ‘Šsubscriptğ»ğ¿Î”ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ¾Î”ğ‘Š\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}\approx H_{L}\Delta W,\quad\frac{\partial\tilde{E% }}{\partial W}\approx K\Delta W,divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‰ˆ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_W , divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‰ˆ italic_K roman_Î” italic_W ,

where HLsubscriptğ»ğ¿H_{L}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Hessian of Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and Kğ¾Kitalic_K is the Lipschitz constant for E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ). Thus, the perturbation dynamics become:

Î”â¢WË™=âˆ’(HL+Kâ¢I)â¢Î”â¢W.Ë™Î”ğ‘Šsubscriptğ»ğ¿ğ¾ğ¼Î”ğ‘Š\dot{\Delta W}=-(H_{L}+KI)\Delta W.overË™ start_ARG roman_Î” italic_W end_ARG = - ( italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_K italic_I ) roman_Î” italic_W .

Let Î»minsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\min}italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the minimum eigenvalue of HL+Kâ¢Isubscriptğ»ğ¿ğ¾ğ¼H_{L}+KIitalic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_K italic_I. Then, solving the differential equation, we obtain:

â€–Î”â¢Wâ¢(t)â€–â‰¤â€–Î”â¢Wâ¢(0)â€–â¢eâˆ’Î»minâ¢t+Oâ¢(Ïµ).normÎ”ğ‘Šğ‘¡normÎ”ğ‘Š0superscriptğ‘’subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡ğ‘‚italic-Ïµ\|\Delta W(t)\|\leq\|\Delta W(0)\|e^{-\lambda_{\min}t}+O(\epsilon).âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W ( 0 ) âˆ¥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_O ( italic_Ïµ ) .

This proves that Î”â¢Wâ¢(t)Î”ğ‘Šğ‘¡\Delta W(t)roman_Î” italic_W ( italic_t ) decays exponentially, establishing that PCNs converge exponentially to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and are robust to small perturbations. âˆ

Appendix E Quasi-Newton Updates

E.1 Proof of Theorem 3.7

Theorem E.1.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a neural network that minimizes a free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the loss function and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is the residual energy. Assume the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives fâ€²,fâ€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²f^{\prime},f^{\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and fâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ‘“â€²â€²â€²f^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are Lipschitz continuous with constants K,Kâ€²,Kâ€²â€²,ğ¾superscriptğ¾â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²K,K^{\prime},K^{\prime\prime},italic_K , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , and Kâ€²â€²â€²superscriptğ¾â€²â€²â€²K^{\prime\prime\prime}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Then, the PC updates approximate quasi-Newton updates by incorporating higher-order information through the residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG.

Proof.

Step 1: PC Update Rule The Predictive Coding (PC) update rule for the weights Wlsubscriptğ‘Šğ‘™W_{l}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at layer lğ‘™litalic_l is given by:

Î”â¢Wl=âˆ’Î·â¢(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚Wl+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wl),Î”subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™ğœ‚ğ¿subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™~ğ¸subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™\Delta W_{l}=-\eta\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W_{l}}+\frac{\partial\tilde% {E}}{\partial W_{l}}\right),roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_Î· ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ,

where Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· is the learning rate, Lğ¿Litalic_L is the loss function, and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is an auxiliary residual energy term.

Step 2: Taylor Series Expansion We perform a Taylor series expansion of Lğ¿Litalic_L around the current weight Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W:

Lâ¢(W+Î”â¢W)â‰ˆLâ¢(W)+âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)Tâ¢Î”â¢W+12â¢Î”â¢WTâ¢Hâ¢Î”â¢W+Oâ¢(â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–3),ğ¿ğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡ğ¿superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡Î”ğ‘Š12Î”superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ»Î”ğ‘Šğ‘‚superscriptnormÎ”ğ‘Š3L(W+\Delta W)\approx L(W)+\nabla L(W)^{T}\Delta W+\frac{1}{2}\Delta W^{T}H% \Delta W+O(\|\Delta W\|^{3}),italic_L ( italic_W + roman_Î” italic_W ) â‰ˆ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_W + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H roman_Î” italic_W + italic_O ( âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where Hğ»Hitalic_H is the Hessian matrix of Lğ¿Litalic_L at Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W. Similarly, expanding E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG around Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W:

E~â¢(W+Î”â¢W)â‰ˆE~â¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W)Tâ¢Î”â¢W+12â¢Î”â¢WTâ¢H~â¢Î”â¢W+Oâ¢(â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–3),~ğ¸ğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡Î”ğ‘Š12Î”superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡~ğ»Î”ğ‘Šğ‘‚superscriptnormÎ”ğ‘Š3\tilde{E}(W+\Delta W)\approx\tilde{E}(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)^{T}\Delta W+\frac{% 1}{2}\Delta W^{T}\tilde{H}\Delta W+O(\|\Delta W\|^{3}),over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W + roman_Î” italic_W ) â‰ˆ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_W + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W + italic_O ( âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where H~~ğ»\tilde{H}over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG is the Hessian matrix of E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG.

Step 3: Combined Free Energy Expansion Combining the expansions of Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, the total free energy F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG can be approximated as:

Fâ¢(W+Î”â¢W)â‰ˆFâ¢(W)+(âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W))Tâ¢Î”â¢W+12â¢Î”â¢WTâ¢(H+H~)â¢Î”â¢W+Oâ¢(â€–Î”â¢Wâ€–3).ğ¹ğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šsuperscriptâˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸ğ‘Šğ‘‡Î”ğ‘Š12Î”superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ»~ğ»Î”ğ‘Šğ‘‚superscriptnormÎ”ğ‘Š3F(W+\Delta W)\approx F(W)+\left(\nabla L(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)\right)^{T}% \Delta W+\frac{1}{2}\Delta W^{T}(H+\tilde{H})\Delta W+O(\|\Delta W\|^{3}).italic_F ( italic_W + roman_Î” italic_W ) â‰ˆ italic_F ( italic_W ) + ( âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_W + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) roman_Î” italic_W + italic_O ( âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Step 4: Minimizing the Free Energy To minimize Fğ¹Fitalic_F, we set the gradient of the quadratic approximation to zero:

âˆ‡Fâ¢(W+Î”â¢W)â‰ˆâˆ‡Fâ¢(W)+(H+H~)â¢Î”â¢W=0.âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘Šâˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘Šğ»~ğ»Î”ğ‘Š0\nabla F(W+\Delta W)\approx\nabla F(W)+(H+\tilde{H})\Delta W=0.âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_W + roman_Î” italic_W ) â‰ˆ âˆ‡ italic_F ( italic_W ) + ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) roman_Î” italic_W = 0 .

Solving for Î”â¢WÎ”ğ‘Š\Delta Wroman_Î” italic_W:

Î”â¢W=âˆ’(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢(âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W)).Î”ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸ğ‘Š\Delta W=-(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}\left(\nabla L(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)\right).roman_Î” italic_W = - ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ) .

Step 5: Comparison with Quasi-Newton Updates In quasi-Newton methods, the weight update rule is:

Î”â¢W=âˆ’Bâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W),Î”ğ‘Šsuperscriptğµ1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W=-B^{-1}\nabla L(W),roman_Î” italic_W = - italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) ,

where Bâ‰ˆHğµğ»B\approx Hitalic_B â‰ˆ italic_H is an approximation to the Hessian matrix. Comparing this with the PC update:

Î”â¢WPC=âˆ’(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢(âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W)),Î”subscriptğ‘ŠPCsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{PC}}=-(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}\left(\nabla L(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)% \right),roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ) ,

we see that the PC updates incorporate an additional term H~~ğ»\tilde{H}over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG, which adjusts the curvature approximation to include higher-order information. This makes (H+H~)âˆ’1superscriptğ»~ğ»1(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a refined approximation of the inverse Hessian.

Step 6: Stability and Convergence The presence of the residual energy term E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG in the updates ensures that the direction of the gradient descent is better aligned with the curvature of the energy landscape. Thus, the PC updates provide a more stable update rule compared to standard gradient descent, similar to quasi-Newton methods.

Therefore, the PC updates approximate quasi-Newton updates by incorporating a refined curvature correction through E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, leading to improved stability and convergence.

âˆ

E.2 Proof of Theorem 3.8

Theorem E.2.

Let Mğ‘€Mitalic_M be a neural network minimizing a free energy function F=L+E~ğ¹ğ¿~ğ¸F=L+\tilde{E}italic_F = italic_L + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, where Lğ¿Litalic_L is the loss function and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is a residual energy term. Let HGN=JTâ¢Jsubscriptğ»GNsuperscriptğ½ğ‘‡ğ½H_{\text{GN}}=J^{T}Jitalic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J denote the Gauss-Newton matrix, where Jğ½Jitalic_J is the Jacobian matrix of the networkâ€™s output with respect to the parameters. Consider the following update rules:

- Quasi-Newton (QN) Update: Î”â¢WQN=âˆ’HGNâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)Î”subscriptğ‘ŠQNsuperscriptsubscriptğ»GN1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{QN}}=-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1}\nabla L(W)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ),

- Target Propagation (TP) Update: Î”â¢WTP=âˆ’Blâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)Î”subscriptğ‘ŠTPsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘™1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{TP}}=-B_{l}^{-1}\nabla L(W)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ), where Blsubscriptğµğ‘™B_{l}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a block-diagonal approximation of HGNsubscriptğ»GNH_{\text{GN}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

- Predictive Coding (PC) Update: Î”â¢WPC=âˆ’(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢(âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W))Î”subscriptğ‘ŠPCsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{PC}}=-(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}\left(\nabla L(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)\right)roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ).

Assume that Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) are twice differentiable, and the activation function fğ‘“fitalic_f and its derivatives are Lipschitz continuous. Then, the approximation error between the updates and the true Quasi-Newton update satisfies:

EPCâ‰¤ETP,subscriptğ¸PCsubscriptğ¸TPE_{\text{PC}}\leq E_{\text{TP}},italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where:

EPC=â€–Î”â¢WPCâˆ’Î”â¢WQNâ€–,ETP=â€–Î”â¢WTPâˆ’Î”â¢WQNâ€–.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¸PCnormÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠPCÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠQNsubscriptğ¸TPnormÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠTPÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠQNE_{\text{PC}}=\|\Delta W_{\text{PC}}-\Delta W_{\text{QN}}\|,\quad E_{\text{TP}% }=\|\Delta W_{\text{TP}}-\Delta W_{\text{QN}}\|.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

Thus, Predictive Coding is mathematically closer to the true Quasi-Newton updates than Target Propagation.

Proof.

Step 1: Derive the True Gauss-Newton Update The true Gauss-Newton (GN) update for the weights Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is given by:

Î”â¢WQN=âˆ’HGNâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W),Î”subscriptğ‘ŠQNsuperscriptsubscriptğ»GN1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{QN}}=-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1}\nabla L(W),roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) ,

where HGN=JTâ¢Jsubscriptğ»GNsuperscriptğ½ğ‘‡ğ½H_{\text{GN}}=J^{T}Jitalic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_J start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_J is the Gauss-Newton matrix. Here, Jğ½Jitalic_J is the Jacobian matrix of the networkâ€™s outputs yğ‘¦yitalic_y with respect to the parameters Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W, i.e., J=âˆ‚yâˆ‚Wğ½ğ‘¦ğ‘ŠJ=\frac{\partial y}{\partial W}italic_J = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_y end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG.

Step 2: Derive Target Propagation (TP) Update Target Propagation updates the weights using a block-diagonal approximation of the GN matrix:

Î”â¢WTP=âˆ’Blâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W),Î”subscriptğ‘ŠTPsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘™1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{TP}}=-B_{l}^{-1}\nabla L(W),roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) ,

where Blâ‰ˆHGNsubscriptğµğ‘™subscriptğ»GNB_{l}\approx H_{\text{GN}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a block-diagonal matrix that approximates the full curvature information. Because Blsubscriptğµğ‘™B_{l}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ignores off-diagonal elements of HGNsubscriptğ»GNH_{\text{GN}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it captures less curvature information. Thus, the error between TP and GN is given by:

ETP=â€–Î”â¢WTPâˆ’Î”â¢WQNâ€–=â€–Î·â¢(Blâˆ’1âˆ’HGNâˆ’1)â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)â€–.subscriptğ¸TPnormÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠTPÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠQNnormğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ»GN1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘ŠE_{\text{TP}}=\|\Delta W_{\text{TP}}-\Delta W_{\text{QN}}\|=\|\eta(B_{l}^{-1}-% H_{\text{GN}}^{-1})\nabla L(W)\|.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ italic_Î· ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) âˆ¥ .

Step 3: Predictive Coding (PC) Update The Predictive Coding update is derived by minimizing the free energy:

Fâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W),ğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠF(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W),italic_F ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ,

where E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) is a residual energy term. The PC update rule is:

Î”â¢WPC=âˆ’(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢(âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W)).Î”subscriptğ‘ŠPCsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{PC}}=-(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}\left(\nabla L(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)% \right).roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ) .

Step 4: Second-Order Analysis for Predictive Coding Using a Taylor series expansion for Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, we have:

Lâ¢(W+Î”â¢W)â‰ˆLâ¢(W)+âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)Tâ¢Î”â¢W+12â¢Î”â¢WTâ¢Hâ¢Î”â¢W,ğ¿ğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Šâˆ‡ğ¿superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡Î”ğ‘Š12Î”superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡ğ»Î”ğ‘ŠL(W+\Delta W)\approx L(W)+\nabla L(W)^{T}\Delta W+\frac{1}{2}\Delta W^{T}H% \Delta W,italic_L ( italic_W + roman_Î” italic_W ) â‰ˆ italic_L ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_W + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H roman_Î” italic_W ,

where H=âˆ‚2Lâˆ‚W2ğ»superscript2ğ¿superscriptğ‘Š2H=\frac{\partial^{2}L}{\partial W^{2}}italic_H = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG is the Hessian of Lğ¿Litalic_L. Similarly, expanding E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) around Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W:

E~â¢(W+Î”â¢W)â‰ˆE~â¢(W)+âˆ‡E~â¢(W)Tâ¢Î”â¢W+12â¢Î”â¢WTâ¢H~â¢Î”â¢W,~ğ¸ğ‘ŠÎ”ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Šâˆ‡~ğ¸superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡Î”ğ‘Š12Î”superscriptğ‘Šğ‘‡~ğ»Î”ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W+\Delta W)\approx\tilde{E}(W)+\nabla\tilde{E}(W)^{T}\Delta W+\frac{% 1}{2}\Delta W^{T}\tilde{H}\Delta W,over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W + roman_Î” italic_W ) â‰ˆ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) + âˆ‡ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” italic_W + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG roman_Î” italic_W ,

where H~=âˆ‚2E~âˆ‚W2~ğ»superscript2~ğ¸superscriptğ‘Š2\tilde{H}=\frac{\partial^{2}\tilde{E}}{\partial W^{2}}over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

Step 5: Combining the Hessians The total second-order curvature matrix for PC is given by:

HPC=H+H~.subscriptğ»PCğ»~ğ»H_{\text{PC}}=H+\tilde{H}.italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG .

The PC update becomes:

Î”â¢WPC=âˆ’(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W).Î”subscriptğ‘ŠPCsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Š\Delta W_{\text{PC}}=-(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}\nabla L(W).roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) .

Step 6: Error Analysis for PC and TP The error between PC and GN is:

EPC=â€–Î”â¢WPCâˆ’Î”â¢WQNâ€–=â€–Î·â¢(H+H~)âˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)âˆ’HGNâˆ’1â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)â€–.subscriptğ¸PCnormÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠPCÎ”subscriptğ‘ŠQNnormğœ‚superscriptğ»~ğ»1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ»GN1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘ŠE_{\text{PC}}=\|\Delta W_{\text{PC}}-\Delta W_{\text{QN}}\|=\|\eta(H+\tilde{H}% )^{-1}\nabla L(W)-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1}\nabla L(W)\|.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Î” italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT QN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ italic_Î· ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) âˆ¥ .

The error between TP and GN is:

ETP=â€–Î·â¢(Blâˆ’1âˆ’HGNâˆ’1)â¢âˆ‡Lâ¢(W)â€–.subscriptğ¸TPnormğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ»GN1âˆ‡ğ¿ğ‘ŠE_{\text{TP}}=\|\eta(B_{l}^{-1}-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1})\nabla L(W)\|.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âˆ¥ italic_Î· ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ‡ italic_L ( italic_W ) âˆ¥ .

Step 7: Comparison of Error Norms Using matrix perturbation theory and the fact that H+H~â‰ˆHGNğ»~ğ»subscriptğ»GNH+\tilde{H}\approx H_{\text{GN}}italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG â‰ˆ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a better approximation than Blâ‰ˆHGNsubscriptğµğ‘™subscriptğ»GNB_{l}\approx H_{\text{GN}}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have:

â€–(H+H~)âˆ’1âˆ’HGNâˆ’1â€–â‰¤â€–Blâˆ’1âˆ’HGNâˆ’1â€–.normsuperscriptğ»~ğ»1superscriptsubscriptğ»GN1normsuperscriptsubscriptğµğ‘™1superscriptsubscriptğ»GN1\|(H+\tilde{H})^{-1}-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1}\|\leq\|B_{l}^{-1}-H_{\text{GN}}^{-1}\|.âˆ¥ ( italic_H + over~ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT GN end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ .

Thus, we conclude:

EPCâ‰¤ETP.subscriptğ¸PCsubscriptğ¸TPE_{\text{PC}}\leq E_{\text{TP}}.italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

âˆ

E.3 PROOF OF THEOREM 3.9

Theorem E.3.

Let DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represent two dynamical systems corresponding to predictive coding (PC) and target propagation (TP), respectively. Assume that both systems have the same equilibrium point Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the loss functions Lğ¿Litalic_L and residual energy E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are twice differentiable and positive definite. Furthermore, let the activation functions flsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘™f_{l}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and their derivatives be Lipschitz continuous. Define the Lyapunov functions:

  1. 1.

    For predictive coding: VPCâ¢(W)=Fâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W)subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=F(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_F ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ).

  2. 2.

    For target propagation: VTPâ¢(W)=âˆ‘l=1L12â¢â€–tlâˆ’flâ¢(Wlâ¢tlâˆ’1)â€–2subscriptğ‘‰TPğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿12superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™12V_{\text{TP}}(W)=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\frac{1}{2}\|t_{l}-f_{l}(W_{l}t_{l-1})\|^{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Then, it follows that PC is more stable than TP according to the following criteria:

  1. 1.

    Convergence Rate: DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges faster to its equilibrium point compared to DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  2. 2.

    Deviation from Equilibrium: DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exhibits a smaller deviation from the equilibrium compared to DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the same initial perturbation.

  3. 3.

    Region of Attraction: The region of attraction for DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is larger than that of DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Let DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represent the two dynamical systems for Predictive Coding (PC) and Target Propagation (TP), respectively, with a shared equilibrium point Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Define the Lyapunov functions for each system as:

1. For Predictive Coding (PC):

VPCâ¢(W)=Fâ¢(W)=Lâ¢(W)+E~â¢(W),subscriptğ‘‰PCğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘ŠV_{\text{PC}}(W)=F(W)=L(W)+\tilde{E}(W),italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = italic_F ( italic_W ) = italic_L ( italic_W ) + over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) ,

where Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) is the backpropagation loss, and E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) is the residual energy. Both Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG are positive definite and twice differentiable, satisfying Fâ¢(W)>0ğ¹ğ‘Š0F(W)>0italic_F ( italic_W ) > 0 for Wâ‰ Wâˆ—ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘ŠW\neq W^{*}italic_W â‰  italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Fâ¢(Wâˆ—)=0ğ¹superscriptğ‘Š0F(W^{*})=0italic_F ( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0.

2. For Target Propagation (TP):

VTPâ¢(W)=âˆ‘l=1L12â¢â€–tlâˆ’flâ¢(Wlâ¢tlâˆ’1)â€–2,subscriptğ‘‰TPğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿12superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™12V_{\text{TP}}(W)=\sum_{l=1}^{L}\frac{1}{2}\|t_{l}-f_{l}(W_{l}t_{l-1})\|^{2},italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where tlsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™t_{l}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the target at layer lğ‘™litalic_l, and flsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘™f_{l}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the activation function. Step 1: Convergence Rate Analysis To analyze convergence, we evaluate the time derivative of each Lyapunov function along the trajectories of DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

1. For Predictive Coding: The PCN dynamics follow:

WË™=âˆ’âˆ‚Fâˆ‚W=âˆ’(âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W).Ë™ğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\dot{W}=-\frac{\partial F}{\partial W}=-\left(\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+% \frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG = - ( divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ) .

The time derivative of VPCsubscriptğ‘‰PCV_{\text{PC}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT along the systemâ€™s trajectory is:

VË™PCâ¢(W)=âˆ‚Fâˆ‚Wâ‹…WË™=âˆ’â€–âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wâ€–2.subscriptË™ğ‘‰PCğ‘Šâ‹…ğ¹ğ‘ŠË™ğ‘Šsuperscriptnormğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š2\dot{V}_{\text{PC}}(W)=\frac{\partial F}{\partial W}\cdot\dot{W}=-\left\|\frac% {\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG â‹… overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Because E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) is positive definite and its derivative âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W~ğ¸ğ‘Š\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG is Lipschitz continuous, âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚Wğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial\tilde{E}}{\partial W}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG is smoother and the gradient descent is more directed, resulting in faster convergence.

2. For Target Propagation: The TP dynamics are given by:

WË™=âˆ’âˆ‘l=1Lâˆ‚âˆ‚Wâ¢(12â¢â€–tlâˆ’flâ¢(Wlâ¢tlâˆ’1)â€–2).Ë™ğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿ğ‘Š12superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™12\dot{W}=-\sum_{l=1}^{L}\frac{\partial}{\partial W}\left(\frac{1}{2}\|t_{l}-f_{% l}(W_{l}t_{l-1})\|^{2}\right).overË™ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG âˆ‚ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

The time derivative of VTPsubscriptğ‘‰TPV_{\text{TP}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is:

VË™TPâ¢(W)=âˆ’âˆ‘l=1Lâ€–âˆ‚âˆ‚Wâ¢(12â¢â€–tlâˆ’flâ¢(Wlâ¢tlâˆ’1)â€–2)â€–2.subscriptË™ğ‘‰TPğ‘Šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿superscriptnormğ‘Š12superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™subscriptğ‘“ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Šğ‘™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™122\dot{V}_{\text{TP}}(W)=-\sum_{l=1}^{L}\left\|\frac{\partial}{\partial W}\left(% \frac{1}{2}\|t_{l}-f_{l}(W_{l}t_{l-1})\|^{2}\right)\right\|^{2}.overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG âˆ¥ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Since the updates are layer-wise and the errors are not adjusted by residual terms, VË™TPâ¢(W)subscriptË™ğ‘‰TPğ‘Š\dot{V}_{\text{TP}}(W)overË™ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W ) decreases more slowly, resulting in a slower convergence rate.

Step 2: Deviation from Equilibrium Let Wâ¢(t)ğ‘Šğ‘¡W(t)italic_W ( italic_t ) represent the trajectory of the system starting from Wâ¢(0)ğ‘Š0W(0)italic_W ( 0 ). We want to show that â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Š\|W(t)-W^{*}\|âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ is smaller for DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT than for DTPsubscriptğ·TPD_{\text{TP}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

1. Predictive Coding: Because E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ) introduces additional regularization, the effective gradient at any point is:

âˆ‚Fâˆ‚W=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚W+âˆ‚E~âˆ‚W.ğ¹ğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Š~ğ¸ğ‘Š\frac{\partial F}{\partial W}=\frac{\partial L}{\partial W}+\frac{\partial% \tilde{E}}{\partial W}.divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_F end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_L end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG + divide start_ARG âˆ‚ over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_W end_ARG .

This sum reduces oscillations and aligns the gradient directions of Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG, causing Wâ¢(t)ğ‘Šğ‘¡W(t)italic_W ( italic_t ) to move more directly toward Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with fewer deviations.

To formalize this, consider a small perturbation Î´â¢Wğ›¿ğ‘Š\delta Witalic_Î´ italic_W from Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then:

â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–â‰ˆâ€–Î´â¢Wâ¢(t)â€–â‰ˆâ€–Î´â¢Wâ¢(0)â€–â¢eâˆ’Î»â¢t,normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šnormğ›¿ğ‘Šğ‘¡normğ›¿ğ‘Š0superscriptğ‘’ğœ†ğ‘¡\|W(t)-W^{*}\|\approx\|\delta W(t)\|\approx\|\delta W(0)\|e^{-\lambda t},âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰ˆ âˆ¥ italic_Î´ italic_W ( italic_t ) âˆ¥ â‰ˆ âˆ¥ italic_Î´ italic_W ( 0 ) âˆ¥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î» italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where Î»=minâ¡(Î»1,Î»2)ğœ†subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†2\lambda=\min(\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2})italic_Î» = roman_min ( italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the smallest eigenvalue of the Hessians of Lğ¿Litalic_L and E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG. Since E~~ğ¸\tilde{E}over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG is positive definite and its Hessian is non-zero, Î»ğœ†\lambdaitalic_Î» is larger for DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, resulting in a smaller deviation.

2. Target Propagation: For TP, without the residual correction, the deviation behaves as:

â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–â‰ˆâ€–Î´â¢Wâ¢(0)â€–â¢eâˆ’Î¼â¢t,normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Šnormğ›¿ğ‘Š0superscriptğ‘’ğœ‡ğ‘¡\|W(t)-W^{*}\|\approx\|\delta W(0)\|e^{-\mu t},âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰ˆ âˆ¥ italic_Î´ italic_W ( 0 ) âˆ¥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î¼ italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where Î¼ğœ‡\muitalic_Î¼ is determined by the smallest eigenvalue of the Hessian of Lğ¿Litalic_L. Because Î¼<Î»ğœ‡ğœ†\mu<\lambdaitalic_Î¼ < italic_Î», the deviation â€–Wâ¢(t)âˆ’Wâˆ—â€–normğ‘Šğ‘¡superscriptğ‘Š\|W(t)-W^{*}\|âˆ¥ italic_W ( italic_t ) - italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ remains larger over time.

Step 3: Region of Attraction The region of attraction is defined as the set of initial points Wâ¢(0)ğ‘Š0W(0)italic_W ( 0 ) such that the system converges to Wâˆ—superscriptğ‘ŠW^{*}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

1. Predictive Coding: With the stabilizing term E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ), the energy landscape is smoother, increasing the region of attraction. Mathematically, the region of attraction is defined as:

â„›PC={W|Fâ¢(W)â‰¤câ¢for someâ¢c>0}.subscriptâ„›PCconditional-setğ‘Šğ¹ğ‘Šğ‘for someğ‘0\mathcal{R}_{\text{PC}}=\left\{W\,\big{|}\,F(W)\leq c\,\text{for some}\,c>0% \right\}.caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_W | italic_F ( italic_W ) â‰¤ italic_c for some italic_c > 0 } .

2. Target Propagation: Without the smoothing effect of E~â¢(W)~ğ¸ğ‘Š\tilde{E}(W)over~ start_ARG italic_E end_ARG ( italic_W ), the region of attraction is:

â„›TP={W|Lâ¢(W)â‰¤câ€²â¢for someâ¢câ€²>0},subscriptâ„›TPconditional-setğ‘Šğ¿ğ‘Šsuperscriptğ‘â€²for somesuperscriptğ‘â€²0\mathcal{R}_{\text{TP}}=\left\{W\,\big{|}\,L(W)\leq c^{\prime}\,\text{for some% }\,c^{\prime}>0\right\},caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT TP end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_W | italic_L ( italic_W ) â‰¤ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0 } ,

which is smaller because Lâ¢(W)ğ¿ğ‘ŠL(W)italic_L ( italic_W ) alone does not account for complex dependencies between layers.

This analysis shows that Predictive Coding has a faster convergence rate, smaller deviation, and larger region of attraction than Target Propagation, making DPCsubscriptğ·PCD_{\text{PC}}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT PC end_POSTSUBSCRIPT more stable, which proves the theorem.
